editionStmt.edition: This early release includes some 500 EEBO-TCP transcriptions of Early Modern plays that have undergone several routines to create an interoperable and algorithmically amenable corpus of Early Modern Drama. Many incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words have been corrected, including obvious printers' errors, but the text has not been proofread word by word. Each word in the text has been identified as a distinct token with its own xml:id and assigned to a lemma, a part of speech, and a standard spelling. Speech prefixes were mapped to unique speaker ID's as "who" attributes of sp elements. elements

respStmt.resp: Incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words were reviewed and in many cases fixed by
respStmt.name: Madeline Burg

respStmt.name: Philip R. Burns

respStmt.resp: With the help of Thomas L. Berger's Index of Characters in Early Modern English Drama Printed Plays, 1500-1660 speech prefixes were mapped to unique "who" attributes of sp elements by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: A provisional, rudimentry, and algorithmically produced castlist was added as a new div in the back listing each role with their number of speeches sorted from high to low by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

div.head: The first part of the play called wits cabal.

list.head: The actors names.
list.item: Grave temperance, governess to mademoiselle pleasure.
Wanton, excess, ease, idle, surfeit, waiting-maids to mademoiselle Pleasure.

div.head: The first part of the play called wits cabal.
Act i.

sp.speaker: Ambition.
sp.p: I would my parents had kept me up as birds in darkness, when they are taught to sing artificial tunes, that my ears only might have been employed; and as those teachers whistle to birds several times, so would I have had tutors to have read to me several authors, as the best poets, the best historians, the best philosophers, moral and natural, the best grammarians, arithmeticians, mathematicians, logicians, and the like. Thus perchance I might have spoke as eloquently upon every subject, as birds sing sweetly several tunes; but since my education hath been so negligent, I wish I might do some noble action, such as might raise a monumental fame on the dead ashes of my forefathers, that my name might live everlastingly.

div.head: Scene 2.
div.stage: Enter mademoiselle Superbe, and flattery her woman.

sp.speaker: Madam Superbe.
sp.p: I hate to be compared to an inferior, or to have an inferior compared to me: wherefore if I were Jove, I would damn that creature that should compare me to any thing less than myself.

sp.speaker: Flattery.
sp.p: Your ladyship is like a goddess, above all comparison: wherefore I think there is none worthy to match in marriage with you, unless there were some masculine divine creature on earth to equal you, as surely there is none.

sp.speaker: Superbe.
sp.p: I shall not willingly marry, unless it were to have a command over my husband.

sp.speaker: Flattery.
sp.p: But husbands, madam, command wives.

sp.speaker: Superbe.
sp.p: Not those that are divine creatures.

sp.speaker: Flattery.
sp.p: Husbands, madam, are reprobates, and regard not divinity, nor worship earthly deities.

sp.speaker: Superbe.
sp.p: Whilst they are suitors, they worship, and women command their wooing servants.

sp.speaker: Flattery.
sp.p:
The truth is, all suitors do worship with an idolatrous zeal, but their zeals tire at length, as most zeals do, and men are content to be commanded, whilst they are courting servants, and do obey with an industrious
care, and with an humble and respectful demeanour, a submissive and awful countenance, with an admiring and listening ear, pleasing and applausing speech, insomuch as their mistress might think they commanded not only their senses, but also their souls; yet after they are married, they become from being servants, to be masters, and they are so far from obeying, as they command, and instead of an humble and respectful demeanour, and an awful countenance, they will be haughty and surly, and their faces will be clothed in frowns, and instead of an admiring eye and a listening ear, they will neither regard nor take notice of their wives, unless it be to throw a scornful glance, and instead of a pleasing and applausing speech, they will reprove, discommend, or threaten. Thus, although they serve as slaves when they are wooing suitors, yet they rule as tyrants when they are husbands, as all slaves do that come to rule, prove tyrants, like as the most fierce zealous supplicants oft-times prove atheists, or reprobates.

sp.speaker: Superbe.
sp.p: Then I must never marry; for I cannot endure to be commanded, but must be admired and adored.

sp.speaker: Flattery.
sp.p: 'Tis fit you should, being a divine creature, madam.

div.head: Scene 3.
div.stage: Enter mademoiselle pleasure, and grave temperance her governess, and five waiting-maids, namely, wanton, idle, ease, excess, and surfeit.

sp.speaker: Vvanton.
sp.p: Women that love the courtship of men, must change themselves into as many several humours as Protheus shapes; as sometimes gay and merry, sometimes grave and majestical, sometimes melancholy, sometimes bashful and coy, sometimes free and confident, sometimes patient, and sometimes choleric, sometimes silent, and sometimes discursive, according as they find those humours they meet with.

sp.speaker: Ease.
sp.p: Let me tell you, wanton, they must love courtship well, that will take such pains to transform themselves so often, to please, or rather to get lovers.

sp.speaker: Temperance.
sp.p: You say well, ease, but they rather lose than gain by the bargain; for the charge of troublesome observance, is more than the profit they receive therefrom.

sp.speaker: Ease.
sp.p: Truly, mistress Temperance, there is no delight in painstaking, ask my lady pleasure.

sp.speaker: Madam. Pleasure.
sp.p: No truly ease; but a sweet civility, a modest behaviour and countenance, and a pleasing speech, gains more lovers than a metamorphosed humour.

sp.speaker: Temperance.
sp.p: In truth a well-tempered humour is easy to themselves, and delightful to others.

sp.speaker: Wanton.
sp.p: You speak for lovers, but there is a difference betwixt courtship and love; for dull love is contented to be entertained only with plain truth, and is constant to an honest heart, but sprightly courtship delights in extravagancies, lives in varieties, but dies in particulars or singularities.

sp.speaker: Pleasure.
sp.p: True delight lives in true love.

sp.speaker: Temperance
sp.p: And true love lives in temperance.

sp.speaker: Ease.
sp.p: And temperance lives in ease.

sp.speaker: Idle.
sp.p: And ease lives in idleness.

sp.speaker: Wanton.
sp.p: And idleness lives in wantonness, and wantonness lives in pleasure.

sp.speaker: Pleasure.
sp.p: Let me tell you, wanton, that pleasure doth not live in wantonness nor idleness; for pleasure lives in peace, maintained by plenty, instructed by prudence, protected by justice, and governed by grave temperance here.

div.head: Scene 4.
div.stage: Enter monsieur vainglorious, and his man.

sp.speaker: Vainglorious.
sp.p: All the ladies in the city are in love with me, and that woman thinks herself happy that can receive a courtship from me; but I mean to marry none but mademoiselle ambition, nor would I marry her but for my particular ends, for she is rich.

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: She is so, if they be rich that have vast desires. But are you sure you shall have her?

sp.speaker: Vainglorious.
sp.p: Yes, for her friends and I am agreed, and I know she cannot deny me; for what woman would not be proud to marry me?

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: 'Tis said she is a noble lady.

sp.speaker: Vainglorious.
sp.p: Faith she will be but a trouble to me; but I will only keep her for breed, and entertain myself, and lead my life with mademoiselle pleasure, and she shall share of the riches that mademoiselle ambition brings.

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: Now you talk of riches sir, what shall we do with the rich cabinet you bought? must that be carried to mademoiselle Pleasure?

sp.speaker: Vainglorious.
sp.p: Yes, but I have other presents to send along with it, which I will give order for.

div.head: Scene 5.
div.stage: Enter monsieur sensuality, and monsieur censure.

sp.speaker: Sensuality.
sp.p: Live under these laws? I will sooner live under the Turks.

sp.speaker: Censure.
sp.p: What makes thee such an enemy to these laws, monsieur sensuality?

sp.speaker: Sensuality.
sp.p: Why monsieur censure, I am fined a hundred pounds for kissing a mistress, and getting a child.

sp.speaker: Censure.
sp.p: Indeed the Turks government is the only government for such men as would have many wives, concubines, and slaves.

sp.speaker: Sensuality.
sp.p:
Why, he is a slave that lives not under such government; for what greater slavery is there than to be tied to one woman? I am sure our forefathers, who were godly men, were not tied to such slavery; they had
their liberty as the Turks, and such like wise governments, a to have as many wives and mistresses as they please, or at least as many as they can maintain.

sp.speaker: Censure.
sp.p: Although you may think that government wise, because it fits your appetite, yet well-tempered men, 'tis likely, will be of another opinion, as to think the strict canon-laws of Europe are better for the good of commonwealths, and every particular family, by restraining one man to one woman, than to let them have more, or as many as they will.

sp.speaker: Sensuality.
sp.p: If well-tempered men be of that opinion, they are fools, which I will soon prove them to be. As first for the commonwealth, there is nothing more disadvantageous; for those commonwealths flourish with greatest glory, that are fullest populated, by reason populated kingdoms are strongest, both for their own defence, and against foreign enemies, as being able to conquer others by invasions, enlarging their dominions with their numbers, increasing their numbers with their numerous issues, begotten and born from their many wives, concubines, and slaves: when by our niggardly laws kingdoms become uninhabited and barren for want of men to till and manure the ground: and as for our wars, they'd seem as private challenges, and our armies as particular duellers, being met with their seconds to decide their petty quarrels, and to show their valour by the hazard of their lives, and our battles seem slight skirmishes, or like a company or rout that kill each other in an idle fray. Thus in comparison of other empires, all Europe is but as one kingdom, for numbers of men, and martial forces, when by the extent it may be accounted the fourth part of the known world. And as for particular families, want of children breeds discontent, and not only destroys industry, but makes spoil and unthrifts; for those that have no children, they care not what becomes of their goods, lands, or livings, spending them through cluelessness, or through riot: and as for women, it spoils them from being good wives; for being sole mistresses, having no copartners, nor shares, neither of their husbands, children, or estates, and being the only she that is served or attended, embraced, loved, or maintained, grows proud, imperious, insults and domineers, and disputes with her husband for preeminency, and the truth is, for the most part, obtains it. Thus men become slaves to the distaff for quietness' sake, otherwise there is such quarrels and brawleries, that his house and home, that should be his couch of ease, his bed of rest, his peaceable haven, or haven of peace, is for the most part his couch of thorns, his bed of cares, his hell of torments, or tormenting hell, and his whole family are like a tempestuous sea, where passions hurl into factions, and rise in waves of discontent: but when men have an absolute power over their wives, they force them into quiet obedience; and where men have many wives, concubines, and slaves, the women are humbled into a submission, each woman striving which should be most serviceable, and who can get most love and favour; and as for bastards, they are as much the father's children, as those that are got in wedlock.

sp.speaker: Censure.
sp.p: But it is likely that concubines and slaves will be false, and father their children on those that never begotten them.

sp.speaker: Sensuality.
sp.p:
Why so may wives, and 'tis most probable they do so; but as other nations do allow many wives, concubines, and slaves, so they give men power and rule to govern and restrain them; and the men are so wise in other nations, as they suffer no other men but themselves to come
near them, hardly to look at the outside of their seraglio's, as that part of the house they are lodged in.

sp.speaker: Censure.
sp.p: Thou hast spoke so well, and hast made so learned a speech for many wives, concubines, and slaves, as I am converted, and will, if thou wilt, travel into such kingdoms as allow such numbers and varieties, that I may be naturalised to their liberties.

div.head: Scene 6.
div.stage: Enter monsieur satyrical, and monsieur inquisitive.

sp.speaker: Inquisitive.
sp.p: What is the reason, monsieur satyrical, you do not marry?

sp.speaker: Satirical.
sp.p: The reason, monsieur inquisitive, is, that I cannot find a wife fit for me.

sp.speaker: Inquisitive.
sp.p: Why, there are women of all ages, births, humours, statures, shapes, complexions, features, behaviours, and wits. But what think you of marrying the lady Nobilissimo?

sp.speaker: Satirical.
sp.p: She is a lady that outreaches my ambition.

sp.speaker: Inquisitive.
sp.p: What think you of the lady Bellissimo?

sp.speaker: Satyrical.
sp.p: She is a lady for admiration, and not for use.

sp.speaker: Inquisitive.
sp.p: What think you of marrying the lady piety?

sp.speaker: Satyrical.
sp.p: She is a lady to be prayed unto as a saint, not to be embraced as wife.

sp.speaker: Inquisitive.
sp.p: What think you of the lady modesty?

sp.speaker: Satyrical.
sp.p: She is a lady that will not only quench amorous love, but the free matrimonial love.

sp.speaker: Inquisitive.
sp.p: What do you think of the lady sage?

sp.speaker: Satyrical.
sp.p: She is a lady to rule as a husband, and not to be ruled as a wife.

sp.speaker: Inquisitive.
sp.p: What think you of the lady politic?

sp.speaker: Satyrical.
sp.p: She is a lady fitter for counsel than for marriage.

sp.speaker: Inquisitive.
sp.p: What say you to the lady ceremony?

sp.speaker: Satyrical.
sp.p: She is a lady fitter for a princely throne, than the marriage-bed.

sp.speaker: Inquisitive.
sp.p: What say you to the lady poetical?

sp.speaker: Satyrical.
sp.p: She is a lady fitter for contemplation than fruition.

sp.speaker: Inquisitive.
sp.p: What say you to the lady humility?

sp.speaker: Satyrical.
sp.p: She is a lady sooner won than enjoyed.

sp.speaker: Inquisitive.
sp.p: What say you to the lady sprightly?

sp.speaker: Satyrical.
sp.p: She is a lady that will disquiet my rest, being fitter for dancing than sleeping.

sp.speaker: Inquisitive.
sp.p: What say to the lady prodigal?

sp.speaker: Satyrical.
sp.p: She is a lady I might feast with, but could not thrive with.

sp.speaker: Inquisitive.
sp.p: What say you to the lady Vanity?

sp.speaker: Satyrical.
sp.p: She is a lady too various and extravagant for my humour.

sp.speaker: Inquisitive.
sp.p: What say you to the lady Victoria?

sp.speaker: Satyrical.
sp.p: She is a lady I had rather hear of, than be enslaved by.

sp.speaker: Inquisitive.
sp.p: What say you to the lady innocent youth?

sp.speaker: Satyrical.
sp.p: She is a lady that may please with embracing, but not with conversing; she is fitter for love than for company, for Cupid than for Pallas, for sport than for counsel.

sp.speaker: Inquisitive.
sp.p: What say you to the lady wanton?

sp.speaker: Satyrical.
sp.p: She is fitter for an hour than for an age.

sp.speaker: Inquisitive.
sp.p: What say you to the lady Poverty?

sp.speaker: Satyrical.
sp.p: She is fitter for my charity than my family.

sp.speaker: Inquisitive.
sp.p: What say you to the lady ill-favoured?

sp.speaker: Satyrical.
sp.p: She is a lady fitter for a nunnery than a nursery; for beads, than for children.

sp.speaker: Inquisitive.
sp.p: What say you to the lady Weakly?

sp.speaker: Satyrical.
sp.p: She is fitter for death than for life; for heaven, than the world.

sp.speaker: Inquisitive.
sp.p: By your answers I perceive you will not marry.

sp.speaker: Satyrical.
sp.p: Have I not reason, when I can find such answers from the sex?

sp.speaker: Inquisitive.
sp.p: But the gods have commanded marriage?

sp.speaker: Satyrical.
sp.p: But saints do choose a single life, and in case of marriage, I will sooner follow the example of the saints, than the commands of the gods.

div.head: Scene 7.
div.stage: Enter mademoiselle ambition, Superbe, Bon' esprit, pleasure, portrait, faction, grave temperance, and mother matron

sp.speaker: Grave temperance.
sp.p: Ladies, what think you of good husbands?

sp.speaker: Portrait.
sp.p: I think well of good husbands.

sp.speaker: Bon' esprit.
sp.p: But it is a question whether good husbands will think well of us.

sp.speaker: Faction.
sp.p: I think good husbands may be in our thoughts, but not actually in the world.

sp.speaker: Ambition.
sp.p: I am of your opinion, they may be mentioned in our words, but not found in our lives.

sp.speaker: Pleasure.
sp.p: Faith we may hear of good husbands, and read of good wives, but they are but romances.

sp.speaker: Portrait.
sp.p: You say right; for we may as soon find an heroic lover, and see all his impossible actions out of a romance book, as a good husbands; but as for wives, I will not declare my opinion.

sp.speaker: Bon' esprit.
sp.p: Nor I; but were there such men that would make good husbands, it were as difficult to get them, as for a romantic lover to get his mistress out of an enchanted castle.

sp.speaker: Pleasure.
sp.p: For my part I had rather die a maid, than take the pains to get a good husband.

sp.speaker: Superbe.
sp.p: I wonder our sex should desire to marry; for when we are unmarried, we are sued and sought to, and not only mistress of ourselves, but our suitors: but when we are married, we are so far from being mistresses, as we become slaves.

sp.speaker: Pleasure.
sp.p: The truth is, there is no act shows us, or rather proves us to be so much fools as we are, as in marrying: for what greater folly can there be, than to put ourselves to that condition which will force us to sue to power, when before that voluntary slavery we were in a condition to use power, and make men sue to us.

sp.speaker: Ambition.
sp.p: We must confess, when we well consider, it is very strange, since every creature naturally desires and strives for preeminency, as to be superior, and not inferior; for all creatures endeavour to command, and are unwilling to obey; for it is not only man, but even the beasts of the field, the birds of the air, and the fishes in the sea; and not only beasts, birds, and fish, but the elements those creatures inhabit in, strive for superiority; only women, who seem to have the meanest souls of all the creatures nature hath made; for women are so far from endeavouring to get power, as they voluntarily give away what they have.

sp.speaker: Portrait.
sp.p: Talk not of women's souls, for men say we have no souls, only beautiful bodies.

sp.speaker: Bon' esprit.
sp.p: But beautiful bodies are a degree of souls, and in my conscience please men better than our souls could do.

sp.speaker: Superbe.
sp.p: If anything prove we have no souls, it is in letting men make such fools of us.

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: Come, come ladies, by women's actions they prove to have more, or at least better souls than men have, for the best parts of the soul are love and generosity, and women have more of either than men have.

sp.speaker: Grave temperance.
sp.p: The truth is, that although reason and understanding are the largest parts of the soul, yet love and generosity are the delicatest parts of the soul.

sp.speaker: Heroick.
sp.p: Good-morrow young ladies, you appear this morning like sweet-smelling flowers, some as roses, others as lilies, others as violets, pinks, and primroses, and your associating in a company together, is like as a posy which love hath bound up into one bucket, which is a fit present for the gods.

sp.speaker: Bon' esprit.
sp.p: If you would have us presented to the gods, we must die; for we are never preferred to them but by death: wherefore we must be given to death, before the gods can have us; they may hear us whilst we live, and we may hear of them, but partake of neither until we die.

sp.speaker: Heroick.
sp.p: O that were pity, ladies; for there is nothing more sad in nature, than when death parts a witty soul from a young beautiful body, before the one hath built monuments of memory, and the other gained trophies of lovers: and as for the gods, you will be as acceptable to them when you are old, as when you are young.

sp.speaker: Ambition.
sp.p: As nothing could make me so sad as untimely death of youth, wit, and beauty, so there is nothing could anger me more, as for fortune to frown upon merit, or not to advance it according to its worth, or to bury it in oblivion, hindering the passage into fame's palace.

sp.speaker: Temperance.
sp.p: For my part, I believe death will neither call nor come for you before his natural time, if you do not send surfeit and excess to call him to take you away.

sp.speaker: Pleasure.
sp.p:
Indeed mankind seem as if they were death's factors; for they
do strive to engross and destroy all other creatures, or at least as many as they can; and not only other creatures, but their own kind, as in wars; and not only their own kind, but themselves, in idle and unprofitable adventures, and gluttonous excess, thus as I said, they are death's factors, buying sickness with health, hoping to gain pleasure, and to make delight their profit, but they are cozened, for they only get diseases, pains, and aches.

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: Pray ladies mark how far you are gone from the text of your discourse, as from sweet-smelling flowers to stinking carrion, which are dead carcases; from a lively good-morrow, to a dead farewell; from mirth to sadness.

sp.speaker: Portrait.
sp.p: You say right, mother matron; wherefore pray leave off this discourse, for I hate to hear off death; for the thoughts of death affright me so, as I can take no pleasure of life when he is in my mind.

sp.speaker: Heroick.
sp.p: Why ladies, the thought of death is more than death himself; for thoughts are sensible or imaginable things, but death himself is neither sensible nor imaginable.

sp.speaker: Portrait.
sp.p: Therefore I would not think of him; and when I am dead, I am past thinking.

sp.speaker: Superbe.
sp.p: Let us discourse of something that is more pleasing than death.

sp.speaker: Heroick.
sp.p: Then by my consent, ladies, your discourse shall be of Venus and Cupid, which are themes more delightful to your sex, and most contrary to death; for love is hot, and death is cold; love illuminates life, and death quenches life out.

sp.speaker: Bon esprit.
sp.p: Let me tell you sir, love is as apt to burn life out, as death is to quench it out, and I had rather die with cold, than be burned with heat; for cold kills with a dead numbness, when heat kills with a raging madness.

sp.speaker: Pleasure.
sp.p: But lovers are tormented with fears and doubts, which cause cold sweats, fainting of spirits, trembling of limbs; it breaks the sweet repose of sleep, disturbs the quiet peace of the mind, vades the colours of beauty, nips or blasts the blossom of youth, making lovers look withered, before time hath made them old.

sp.speaker: Heroick.
sp.p: It is a sign, lady, you have been in love, you give so right a character of a lover.

sp.speaker: Pleasure.
sp.p: No, there requires not a self-experience to find out a lover's trouble, for the outward actions will declare their inward grief and passion.

sp.speaker: Superbe.
sp.p: Certainly she is in love, but conceals it, she keeps it as a secret.

sp.speaker: Pleasure.
sp.p: Love cannot be secret, the passion divulges itself.

sp.speaker: Portrait.
sp.p: Confess, are you not in love?

sp.speaker: Faction.
sp.p: Nay she will never confess a secret, unless you tell her one; for those that tell no secrets, shall hear none.

sp.speaker: Portrait.
sp.p: O yes, for a secret is like a child in the womb; for though it be concealed for a time, it will come out at last, only some comes out easier than others, and some before their time.

sp.speaker: Ambition.
sp.p: Nay whensoever a secret comes out, it's untimely.

sp.speaker: Faction.
sp.p: Secrets are like coy ducks, when one is flown out, it draws out others, and returns with many.

sp.speaker: Pleasure.
sp.p: Then like a coy duck I will try if I can draw all you after me.

sp.speaker: Bon' esprit.
sp.p: She shall see she is like a duck, which is like a goose, and we like her, for we will follow her.

div.head: Scene 8.
div.stage: Enter monsiuer tranquillities peace, and his man.

sp.speaker: Tranquil. Peace.
sp.p: Have you been at monsieur busie's house, to tell him I desire to speak with him?

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: Yes, I have been at his house.

sp.speaker: Tranquill. Peace.
sp.p: And will he come?

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: Faith sir the house is too unwieldy to stir, and monsieur busy is too active to stay at home: but the truth is, I went at four o'clock this morning, because I would be sure to find him and his servants, and their master was flown out of his nest an hour before: then I told his servants I would come about dinnertime, and they laughed, and asked me what time was that? I said I supposed at the usual time, about noon, or an hour before or after, but they said their master never kept any certain time of eating, being full of business. Then I asked them what time that would be when he would come home to bed: they answered, that his time of resting was as uncertain as his time of eating. Then I prayed them to tell me at what time they thought I might find him at home: they said it was impossible for them to guess, for that their master did move from place to place, as swift as thoughts move in the mind. Then I prayed them that they would tell him when he came home, that you would desire to speak with him: they told me they would, but they did verily believe he would forget to come to you, by reason his head was so full of busy thoughts, or thoughts of business, as there was no room more for a thought to stay in. So I went away in despair, but coming home, I chanced to see him at a little distance, so I made all the haste I could to overtake him, placing my eyes fixedly upon him, because I would not lose him; but his pace was so swift, and his several turnings in several lanes and allies were so many, as it was impossible for me to keep my measure, pace, or sight, for like a bird, he did not only fly out of my reach, but out of my view; but by a second good fortune, I met him just at your gate, and I stopped his way until I had told him your message, which was, you would speak with him: he answered me, he could not possibly stay, for his business called him another way. I told him, that if he did not come and speak with you, or stay until you did come and speak with him, his lawsuit, which was of great importance, would be lost, for you could not do him any further service to your friends, that should help him, until he had resolved you of some questions you were to ask him; besides that, you wanted a writing that he had. He told me that he was very much obliged to you for your favour to him, but he could not possibly stay to speak with you, for he had some business to do for two or three other men, and he must of necessity go seek those men out whom the business concerned; so that I could not persuade him by any means, although for his own good, to come in, or to stay till you went to him.

sp.speaker: Tranquill. Peace.
sp.p:
Faith he is so busy, that he will neither do himself good
nor any other man; for he runs himself out of the field of business, being overbusy, neither holding the reins of time, nor sitting steady in the seat of judgement, nor stopping with the bit of discretion, nor taking the advantages of opportunity; but totters with inconstancy, and falls with loss. Thus his busy thoughts do tire his mind, so that his life hath a sorry, sore, and weary journey.

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: I think he is a man that is full of projects.

sp.speaker: Tranquill. Peace.
sp.p: So full, as his head is stuffed with them, and he begins many designs, but never finisheth any one of them; for his designs are built upon vain hopes, without a foundation: but were his hopes solid with probability, yet his inconstancy, and unsteady doubts, and over-cautious care, would pull down, or ruin his designs before they were half built.

div.head: Scene 9.
div.stage: Enter Bon' esprit, portrait, ambition, Superbe, pleasure, faction, grave temperance, mother matron.

sp.speaker: Portrait.
sp.p: Monsieur sensuality, let us examine you, what company have you met withal, that hath caused you to break your word with us, when you had promised you would come, and carry us to a play?

sp.speaker: Pleasure.
sp.p: If he carry us all, he will carry a very heavy load.

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: Ladies should be heavy, and not light.

sp.speaker: Portrait.
sp.p: But monsieur sensuality, pray tell us where you have been, and with whom.

sp.speaker: Sensuality.
sp.p: Why I have been with as proper a lady as any is in this city.

sp.speaker: Ambition.
sp.p: What do you mean by a proper lady?

sp.speaker: Bon' esprit.
sp.p: He means a propped lady.

sp.speaker: Sensuality.
sp.p: I mean a tall, proportionable lady, which is a comely sight.

sp.speaker: Faction.
sp.p: Not to my eyes; for I never see a tall big woman, but I think she rather proceeds from the race of Titan than Jove, for she seems to be more body than soul, more earth than flame.

sp.speaker: Sensuality.
sp.p: For my part, I think there cannot be too much of a fair lady; and if I were to choose, I would choose her that had more body than soul, for her soul would be useless to me, by reason souls cannot be enjoyed as bodies are.

sp.speaker: Ambition.
sp.p: Yes, in a spiritual conversation they may.

sp.speaker: Sensuality.
sp.p: I hate an incorporeal conversation.

sp.speaker: Superbe.
sp.p: Why then you hate the conversation of the gods.

sp.speaker: Sensuality.
sp.p: I love the conversation and society of fair young ladies, such as you are.

sp.speaker: Portrait.
sp.p: That is not the answer to my question.

sp.speaker: Sensuality.
sp.p: Then let me tell you, ladies, that most of our sex do venture heaven for your sakes, and will sooner disobey the gods than you.

sp.speaker: Bon' esprit.
sp.p: So you make as if women commanded men against the gods.

sp.speaker: Sensuality.
sp.p: No lady, but we serve women, when we should serve the gods, and pray to your sex, when the gods would have us pray to them.

sp.speaker: Pleasure.
sp.p: The more wicked creatures are men.

sp.speaker: Sensuality.
sp.p: No, the more tempting creatures are women.

sp.speaker: Faction.
sp.p: So you will make us devils at last; for the original of temptation came from Pluto.

sp.speaker: Sensuality.
sp.p: Temptation, lady, was bred in nature, born from nature, and inhabits with all your sex, as with nature's self, whom I have heard is a most beautiful lady, and that is the reason, I suppose, she hath favoured women more than men, being herself of the effeminate sex: and the truth is, nature hath been cruel to our sex; for she hath not only made you so beautiful, as to be admired and desired, but so cruel, as to despise, reject and scorn us, taking pleasure in our torments.

sp.speaker: Portrait.
sp.p: If all women were of my mind, we would torment you more than we do.

sp.speaker: Faction.
sp.p: We have tormented him enough with talking, therefore let us leave him.

sp.speaker: Sensuality.
sp.p: Nay ladies, I will wait upon you.

div.head: Scene 10.
div.stage: Enter monsieur satyrical, and monsieur Frisk.

sp.speaker: Frisk.
sp.p: Monsieur satyrical, I can tell you sad news.

sp.speaker: Satyrical.
sp.p: Let sadness sit upon the grave of death, for I defy it.

sp.speaker: Frisk.
sp.p: But that man is in danger that stands as a centre in a circumference from whence all the malignant passions shoot at him, as suspicion, spite, envy, hatred, malice, and revenge; and the more dangerous, by reason their arrows are poisoned with effeminate rage.

sp.speaker: Satyrical.
sp.p: Let them shoot, for I am armed with carelessness, and have a spell of confidence, which will keep me safe. But who are they that are mine enemies?

sp.speaker: Frisk.
sp.p: No less than a dozen ladies.

sp.speaker: Satyrical.
sp.p: If I can attain to fight with them apart, hand to hand, I make no question but to come off conqueror; and if they assault me altogether, yet I make no doubt but I shall so skirmish amongst them, as I shall be on equal terms. But what makes the breach of peace betwixt me and the ladies, and such a breach as to proclaim open wars?

sp.speaker: Frisk.
sp.p: The cause is just, if it be true as it is reported.

sp.speaker: Satyrical.
sp.p: Why what is reported?

sp.speaker: Frisk.
sp.p: It is reported you have divulged some secret favours those ladies have given you.

sp.speaker: Satyrical.
sp.p: It were ungrateful to conceal a favour: for favours proceed from generous and noble souls, sweet and kind natures.

sp.speaker: Frisk.
sp.p: But ladies' favours are to be concealed and locked up in the closet of secrecy, being given with privacy, and promise not to divulge them; and it seems by report you have broke your promise, for which they swear to be revenged.

sp.speaker: Satyrical.
sp.p: Faith all women, especially ladies, their natural humour is like the sea, which will be neither quiet itself, always ebbing and flowing, nor let any thing be at rest on it: I know not what the fishes are that are in it, but for any thing I can perceive to the contrary, they live in a perpetual motion: so do ladies; for their passions and affections ebb and flow from object to object; for one while they flow with love, then ebb with hate, sometimes they are rough with anger, and stormy with rage, then indifferent calm with patience, but that is seldom: but in the springtide of beauty they overflow all with pride, and their thoughts, like fishes, are in a perpetual motion, swimming from place to place, from company to company, from one meeting to another, and are never at rest.

sp.speaker: Frisk.
sp.p: Thou deservest to die the death of Orpheus.

sp.speaker: Satyrical.
sp.p: 'Tis likely I shall, by reason I am a satirical poet, and women hate satire in poetry, although not wood or forest satyrs; and the most extravagant and maddest actions that ever were done, were done or acted by women, and the truth is, women are not only batchelling some parts of the year, but all their life-long, for they drink vanity, and are mad-drunk with wantonness.

sp.speaker: Frisk.
sp.p: Let me tell you, that if I should be brought as a witness, and should declare the truth, there were no hopes of mercy for thee.

sp.speaker: Satyrical.
sp.p: I grant it, if women were to be my judges.

div.head: Scene 11.
div.stage: Enter excess, wanton, idle, and surfeit.

sp.speaker: Excess.
sp.p: Where shall we go for pastime today? for our lady hath left us to our own: pleasures today.

sp.speaker: Idle.
sp.p: Let us go and swim in a boat upon the river.

sp.speaker: Wanton.
sp.p: That is but a waterish recreation; besides it is very dangerous, for many have been drowned in their idle pastimes.

sp.speaker: Surfet.
sp.p: If you will take my counsel, let us go to the lodge in the park, and drink syllabubs.

sp.speaker: Wanton.
sp.p: Yes, let us go, for the lodge puts me into a good humour, and syllabubs make me merry.

sp.speaker: Idle.
sp.p: You have reason, for it is a cherely cup, and a cup of good fellowship, for we may all eat and drink together.

sp.speaker: Surfet.
sp.p: Yes by spoonfuls.

sp.speaker: Excess.
sp.p:
I love to be drunk by spoonfuls, for then I am drunk by degrees, and not at one draught, as a pint, or a quart at a draught, as men do; besides, though it be allowable for the sobrest noblest women to be drunk with wine-caudles, syllabubs, sack-possets, and the like, so it be by spoonfuls, yet it were abominable and most dishonourable for women to be
drunk with plain wine, and great draught, as men are; besides, in great draughts there is not that pleasure of taste, as in a little at a time.

sp.speaker: Idle.
sp.p: I believe that is the reason that Flemmings love to sip their wine, because they would have the pleasure of taste.

sp.speaker: Wanton.
sp.p: No question but they learned that of the effeminate sex, who love to taste of every thing.

sp.speaker: Surfet.
sp.p: I do believe it; for all women love spoon-meat.

sp.speaker: Excess.
sp.p: 'Tis true, and to drink in spoons.

sp.speaker: Idle.
sp.p: Talk no more of eating and drinking, but eat and drink without talking, and afterwards talk to digest it.

sp.speaker: Excess.
sp.p: And after it is digested, let's eat and drink again.

sp.speaker: Wanton.
sp.p: So we shall do nothing but eat, drink, and talk.

sp.speaker: Surfet.
sp.p: Women do nothing else all their life-long.

sp.speaker: Wanton.
sp.p: By your favour but we do.

sp.speaker: Excess.
sp.p: Come, come, let us go.

sp.speaker: Ambition.
sp.p: O that I might enjoy those pleasures which poets fancy, living in such delight as nature never knew; nor that all poets did write of me, not only to express their wit, but my worth, and that I might be praised by all mankind, yet not vulgarly, as in a crowd of others praises, but my praises to be singularly enthroned above the rest, and that all others commendations might have no other light but what proceeds from the splendour of my fame: also I wish that nature had made me such a beauty, as might have drawn the eyes of the whole world as a loadstone to gaze at it, and the splendour thereof might have enlightened every blind eye, and the beams therefrom might have comforted every sad heart, and the pleasing aspect therein might have turned all passions into love; then would I have had nature, fortune, and the fates, to have given me a free power of the whole world, and all that is therein, that I might have pressed and squeezed our the healing balsams, and sovereign juices, and restoring simples into every sick wounded and decayed body, and every disquieted or distempered mind: likewise, that I might have been able to have relieved those that were poor and necessitous, with the hidden riches therein, and that by my power I might not only have obliged every particular creature and person, according to their worth and merit, but to have made so firm a peace amongst mankind, as never to be dissolved.

div.head: Scene 8.
div.stage: Enter monsieur satyrical, and monsieur inquisitive.

sp.speaker: Inquisitive.
sp.p: I wonder you should be an enemy to women.

sp.speaker: Satyrical.
sp.p: I am so far from being an enemy to the effeminate sex, as I am the best friend they have: for I do as a friend ought to do, which is, to tell them truth, when other men deceive them with flattery.

sp.speaker: Inquisitive.
sp.p: But they complain, and say you exclaim and rail against them.

sp.speaker: Satyrical.
sp.p: Their complaints proceed from their partial self-love and luxury: for they love pleasing flattery, as they do sweetmeats, and hate rigid truth, as they do a bitter potion, although the one destroys their health, the other prolongs their life.

sp.speaker: Inquisitive.
sp.p: But they are so angry, as they all swear, and have made a vow to be revenged on you.

sp.speaker: Satyrical.
sp.p: Let them throw their spleens at me, I will stand their malice, or dart forth amorous glances, they will not pierce my heart: for Pallas is my shield, and Cupid hath no power.

sp.speaker: Inquisitive.
sp.p: If they cannot wound you with their eyes, they will sting you with their tongues, for women are like bees.

sp.speaker: Satyrical.
sp.p: If they are like bees, their stings lie not in their tongues.

div.head: Scene 14.
div.stage: Enter mother matron, Bon' esprit, portrait, faction, ambition, pleasure

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: I can tell you news, ladies.

sp.speaker: Portrait.
sp.p: What news, mother matron?

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: Why there is a rich young heir come to town.

sp.speaker: Superbe.
sp.p: Some foolish son of a miserable father, who hath spared from his back and belly, to make his son vain and prodigal. But what shall we be the better for this rich heir?

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: Why marry if you can get him, you will be so much the better as a rich husband can make you.

sp.speaker: Ambition.
sp.p: He will first be got by the cheats in the town, which cheats have more subtlety, and will be more industrious to get him, than the youngest and beautifullest, and wittiest lady of us all; so as there is no hopes of gaining him, until he is so poor, as he is not worth the having.

sp.speaker: Faction.
sp.p: But if he could be had whilst he were rich, it were no great victory; for I dare say his mother's laundry-maid might be as soon a conqueress, as a great lady: but if we could conquer and imprison monsieur satyrical in loves fetters, that would be a conquest worthy fame's trumpet.

sp.speaker: Pleasure.
sp.p: O that would be such an exploit, as it would be an honour to our sex.

sp.speaker: Bon' esprit.
sp.p: There is nothing I desire more, than to be she that might enfetter him.

sp.speaker: Portrait.
sp.p: I long to ensnare him.

sp.speaker: Ambition.
sp.p: So do I.

sp.speaker: Bon' esprit.
sp.p: Faith I will lay an ambuscado for him.

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: Fie ladies, fie, I am ashamed to hear the designs you have no catch monsieur satyrical; such fair, young, noble ladies to be so wanton, as none will content you but a wild, rough, rude satyr.

sp.speaker: Bon' esprit.
sp.p: If I were sure there were no other ways to get him, I would become a wood-nymph for his sake.

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: You have forgotten the nymph that was turned into a bear.

sp.speaker: Bon' esprit.
sp.p: O she was one of cruel Diana's nymphs; but I will be none of her order.

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: No, I dare swear you will not; for 'tis unlikely you should, when you desire to embrace a satyr.

sp.speaker: Bon' esprit.
sp.p: I do not desire to embrace him, but to enamour him.

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: Well, ladies, your parents gave you to my care and charge; but since you are so wild, to talk of nothing but nymphs, woods, and satyrs, I will resign up the trust which was imposed on me, to your parents again; for I will not adventure my reputation with such wanton young ladies.

sp.speaker: Bon' esprit.
sp.p: Mother matron, let me tell thee, thy reputation is worn out of thee, time hath devoured it, and therefore thou hast no reputation to lose.

div.head: Scene 15.
div.stage: Enter monsieur censure, and monsieur Frisk.

sp.speaker: Frisk.
sp.p: Fath Tom. I have emptied thy pockets.

sp.speaker: Censure.
sp.p: Thou hast picked my pockets with thy juggling dice, for which, if thou wert a woman, and in my power, I would be revenged for my loss.

sp.speaker: Frisk.
sp.p: Why, what would you do if I were a woman?

sp.speaker: Censure.
sp.p: I would condemn thee to a solitary silent life, which to a woman is worse than hell; for company and talking is their heaven, and their tongues are more restless than the sea, their passions more stormy than the winds, and their appetites more unsatiable and devouring than fire; they are lighter than air, more changing than the moon.

sp.speaker: Frisk.
sp.p: What makes thee thus rail at the effeminate sex?

sp.speaker: Censure.
sp.p: Have I not reason, when fortune is of the same gender?

sp.speaker: Frisk.
sp.p: Faith Tom, I must tell.

sp.speaker: Faction.
sp.p: What will you tell?

sp.speaker: Frisk.
sp.p: Why I will tell you, lady, he hath railed most horribly against your sex.

sp.speaker: Faction.
sp.p: That is usual: for all those men which never received, nor hope to receive any favour from our sex, will rail against it.

sp.speaker: Censure.
sp.p: Those men have no reason, lady, to commend you, if they never received neither profit nor pleasure from you; and those that have been cruelly used by your sex, may lawfully rail against it.

sp.speaker: Faction.
sp.p: The laws of honour forbid it.

sp.speaker: Censure.
sp.p: But the laws of nature allow it, and nature is the most prevailing law.

sp.speaker: Faction.
sp.p: Nature's law is for men to love women, and women men, but in you and I there is not that sympathy; for I dislike your sex, as much as you do ours, and could rail with as free a will against it. The truth is, that although I do not hate men, yet I despise them; for all men appear to me either beasts or butterflies, which are either sensual or vain: indeed most men are worse than beasts; for beasts are but according to their kind, when men are degenerated by beastly sensualies, from which they were made; for as most men are worse than beasts, so you are worse than most men.

sp.speaker: Censure.
sp.p: It is a favour, lady, from your sex, to rail against ours; for it is a sign you have considered us, and that we live in your memory, although with your ill opinions; yet it is better to live with enemies, than not to be; and of all men, I have received the greatest favour from the chiefest of your sex, which is yourself, in that you have considered me most, though you have found me worst, yet it proves you have thought of me.

sp.speaker: Faction.
sp.p: If those thoughts and dispraises be favours, I will bind so many together, until they become as thick and hard as steel, of which you may make an armour, to keep your reputation from wounds of reproach.

sp.speaker: Frisk.
sp.p: There Tom. she hath paid thee both for thy railings and compliments.

sp.speaker: Censure.
sp.p: She hath not paid me in current coin.

sp.speaker: Frisk.
sp.p: It will pass for disgrace, I'll warrant thee.

div.head: Scene 16.
div.stage: Enter madam ambition, faction, portrait, Bon' esprit, pleasure.

sp.speaker: Bon 'Esprit.
sp.p: There are but three things a gallant man requires, which is, a horse, a sword, and a mistress.

sp.speaker: Ambition.
sp.p: Yet a gallant man wants generosity; for the greatest honour for a man, is to be generous; for generosity comprises all virtues, good qualities, and sweet graces; for a generous man will never spare his life, purse, nor labour, for the sake of just right, plain truth, honest poverty, distress, misery, or the like; for a generous man hath a courageous, yet compassionate heart, a constant and noble mind, a bountiful hand, an active and industrious life; and he is one that joys more to do good, than others to receive good.

sp.speaker: Pleasure.
sp.p: There are few or none that have such noble souls, as to prefer another's good before their own.

sp.speaker: Portrait.
sp.p: The truth is, men have more promising tongues, than performing deeds.

sp.speaker: Faction.
sp.p: For all I can perceive, man's life is composed of nothing but deceit, treachery, and rapine.

sp.speaker: Bon' esprit.
sp.p: Indeed man's mind is like a forest, and his thoughts, like wild beasts, inhabit therein.

sp.speaker: Ambition.
sp.p: Man's mind is like a sea, where his thoughts, like fishes, swim therein, where some thought are like huge Leviathans, others like great whales, but some are like sprats, shrimps, and minnows.

sp.speaker: Sensuality.
sp.p: What is like a minnow's?

sp.speaker: Ambition.
sp.p: A man's soul.

sp.speaker: Sensuality.
sp.p: It is better have a soul, although no bigger than a minnow's, than none at all, as women have; but if they have, I dare swear it is no bigger than a pin's point.

sp.speaker: Bon' esprit.
sp.p: Very like, which point pricks down thoughts into the brain, and passions in the heart, and writes in the brain witty conceits, if the point be sharp.

sp.speaker: Sensuality.
sp.p: No, no, it serves only to raise their brains with vanity, to engrave their hearts with falsehood, and to scratch out their lives with discontent.

sp.speaker: Pleasure.
sp.p: We oftener scratch out men's lives than our own.

sp.speaker: Sensuality.
sp.p: Nay, you oftener scratch out our honour than our lives.

sp.speaker: Faction.
sp.p: For my part, I have an itch to be scratching.

sp.speaker: Sensuality.
sp.p: I believe you, for you have a vexatious soul.

sp.speaker: Faction.
sp.p: It hath cause to be vexatious, for the point of my soul is whetted with aqua fortis against your sex.

sp.speaker: Sensuality.
sp.p: I'm sure, lady, your tongue is whetted with aqua fortis.

sp.speaker: Faction.
sp.p: So is yours.

sp.speaker: Sensuality.
sp.p: If it be, let us try which point is sharpest.

sp.speaker: Faction.
sp.p: I will leave the trial to time and occasion.

div.head: Scene 17.
div.stage: Enter madam Superbe, and an ancient woman.

sp.speaker: Woman.
sp.p: Madam, I am an humble suitor to your ladyship.

sp.speaker: Superbe.
sp.p: What is your suit?

sp.speaker: Woman.
sp.p: That you will be pleased to take a young maiden into your service of my preferring.

sp.speaker: Superbe.
sp.p: In what place?

sp.speaker: Woman.
sp.p: To wait and attend on your person.

sp.speaker: Superbe.
sp.p:
Let me tell you, that those servants that attend on my person, do usually accompany me in all my pastimes, exercises, and sometimes in conversation:
wherefore they must be such as are well born, well bred, well behaved, modest, and of sweet dispositions, virtuous, and of strict life, otherwise they are not for me; and if I find them not so, I shall soon turn them away.

sp.speaker: Woman.
sp.p: Why madam, even Diana herself, as severe and strict as she was, had some wanton nymphs, that would commit errors; although they seemed all sober and modest, and professed chastity, yet they would slip out of the way and her presence sometimes.

sp.speaker: Superbe.
sp.p: But she never failed to turn them out of her service, and some she cruelly punished; so that what her severity could not prevent, yet her severity did punish; for Diana's practice was not to watch her wanton nymphs, nor to hunt out their evil haunts, or lurking-places, to see their evil actions, but her practice was to hunt the more modest and temperate creatures, which were the beasts of the fields and forests: so, like as Diana, I shall not watch my maids, nor pardon their rude or dishonourable actions.

sp.speaker: Woman.
sp.p: Pray madam try this maid, for she is very honourably born, and well bred, but poor.

sp.speaker: Superbe.
sp.p: I shall not refuse her for poverty: but as I will have some bound for the truth and trust of my vulgar servants, so I will have some bound for the behaviour, virtue, and modesty of my honourable servants, or else I will not take them.

div.head: Scene 18.
div.stage: Enter mother matron, and meets Monsieur Frisk.

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: Monsieur Frisk, you are well met, for I was even now sending a footman for you.

sp.speaker: Frisk.
sp.p: For what, good mother matron?

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: Marry to come to a company of young ladies, who do half long for you.

sp.speaker: Frisk.
sp.p: They shall not lose their longing, if I can help them.

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: Now by my troth, and that is spoke like a gentleman; but let me tell you, there is a great many of them.

sp.speaker: Frisk.
sp.p: Why then there is the more choice.

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: But there is no choosing amongst ladies, you must take better for worse.

sp.speaker: Frisk.
sp.p: There is no worst amongst ladies, they are all fair and good.

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: I'faith I perceive now why the ladies desire your company so much as they do.

sp.speaker: Frisk.
sp.p: Why my dear mother matron?

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p:
Because you speak well of them behind their backs, and promise them much to their faces; and I will assure you, they have as promising
faces as you can promise them; but great promisers are not good.

sp.speaker: Frisk.
sp.p: Will you say the ladies' faces are not good?

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: I say men's promises are not good. But you are very quick with me, monsieur Frisk, to take me upon the hip so suddenly; but, beshrew me, your sudden frisking answer hath put me into a passion, which hath perturbed the sense of my discourse. Lord, lord, what power a villainous word hath over the passions!

sp.speaker: Frisk.
sp.p: If you please, mother matron, a kiss shall ask pardon for your villainous word.

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: And now, by my troth, I have not been kissed by a young gentleman above this twenty years; but now I am in haste, and cannot stay to receive your gift, wherefore I will refer it until another time.

sp.speaker: Frisk.
sp.p: But I may forget to give it.

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: Never fear that, for I shall remember you of it, when time shall serve: but come away, for the ladies will be horrible angry I have stayed so long, for they were all going to dance, for the fiddles were tuned, tables and stools removed, room made, and they in a dancing posture, only they stay for you to frisk them about.

div.head: Scene 19.
div.stage: Enter madam Superbe, and flattery her maid.

sp.speaker: Flattery.
sp.p: Madam, you behaved yourself more familiar today, than your ladyship was wont to do.

sp.speaker: Superbe.
sp.p: 'Tis true, because those I conversed with today were but inferior persons, and I speak more familiar to such persons as are below my quality, than those that are equal to me, to do them grace and favour; and if they take it not so, I can only say my civility was ignorantly placed on foolish and ignorant persons.

div.head: Scene 20.
div.stage: Enter Bon' esprit, portrait, faction, ambition.

sp.speaker: Portrait.
sp.p: Some say poems are not good, unless they be gloriously attired.

sp.speaker: Faction.
sp.p: What do they mean by glorious attire?

sp.speaker: Ambition.
sp.p: Rhetoric.

sp.speaker: Bon' esprit.
sp.p: Why gay words are not wit, no more than a fair face is a good soul; and it is wit which makes poems good, not words.

sp.speaker: Ambition.
sp.p: Indeed rhetoric is no part of the body of wit, no more than of the soul, only it is the outward garment, which is tailor's work.

sp.speaker: Bon' esprit.
sp.p:
Then it seems, as if the grammarians, logicians, and rhetoricians, are the tailors for oratory, who cut shapes, sit places, seam and
few words together to make several eloquent garments, or garments of eloquence, as orations, declarations, expressions, and the like worditive work, as they please, or at least according to the fashion.

sp.speaker: Ambition.
sp.p: They are so.

sp.speaker: Portrait.
sp.p: Why then those that say verse is not good, unless gloriously attired, do as much as to say a man is a fool that hath not a fine suit of clothes on, or, that a curled hair, sweetly powdered, is a wise, or witty brain, powdered with fancies. This surely is an unpardonable mistake, or rather an incurable madness, for there is neither sense nor reason in it.

sp.speaker: Bon' esprit.
sp.p: It is not so much a madness, nor that we call natural fools, but amorous fools, or finical fools, or such as are opinionated fools, or self-conceited fools, or high-bound fools.

sp.speaker: Portrait.
sp.p: High-bound fools? What do you mean by high-bound fools?

sp.speaker: Bon' esprit.
sp.p: Strong-lined fools.

sp.speaker: Faction.
sp.p: Those are learned fools.

sp.speaker: Bon' esprit.
sp.p: No, they are conceited fools; for their strength of wit lies in a conceit.

sp.speaker: Ambition.
sp.p: Those, for the most part, their wit is buried in oblivion.

sp.speaker: Faction.
sp.p: If there be any wit to bury.

sp.speaker: Sensuality.
sp.p: Who is so foolish to bury wit?

sp.speaker: Faction.
sp.p: You, in the rubbish of words.

sp.speaker: Portrait.
sp.p: The only grave to wit is a foolish ear.

sp.speaker: Sensuality.
sp.p: Let me tell you, ladies, that wit is so far from lying in a grave, as it hardly settles anywhere ; for it is so agile, and flies so swiftly, and yet extends in breadth so far, as it spreads the wings of fancy, not only over all the world, and every particular thing in the world, but one infinite and eternal nature, and with the bill of conception picks a hole, whereby the eyes of imagination spy out the dark dungeons of Pluto, and the glorious mansions of Jove.

sp.speaker: Portrait.
sp.p: Then poems need not the garments of rhetoric.

sp.speaker: Sensuality.
sp.p: No more than a fair lady: and as for my part, I like poems as I like a woman, best unclothed, for then I am sure they cannot deceive or delude me with false and feigned shows.

div.head: Scene 21.
div.stage: Enter mademoiselle pleasure, and grave temperance, and her woman.

sp.speaker: Temperance.
sp.p: Madam, will you please to go abroad, and take the cool refreshing air today?

sp.speaker: Pleasure.
sp.p: Yes, temperance, if you will; but I had rather stay and entertain monsieur serious contemplation's company.

sp.speaker: Temperance.
sp.p: Indeed madam I will forbid his frequent visits; for otherwise you will bury yourself in his melancholy conversation.

sp.speaker: Pleasure.
sp.p: Pray do not, for he is the greatest delight in life.

sp.speaker: Temperance.
sp.p: And then he brings such a numerous train of fancies and opinions, as fills up your head, which is the largest room in your bodily house; insomuch, as none of your domestic thoughts, which are the minds usefullest servants, can stir about your life's ordinary affairs.

sp.speaker: Pleasure.
sp.p: Why temperance, fancies are pretty youths, which make harmless and innocent sport, to pass the time away.

sp.speaker: Temperance.
sp.p: We have so little time, as we shall not need to pass it idly away.

sp.speaker: Pleasure.
sp.p: As much as we complain of want of time, we have more than we can tell well how to spend.

sp.speaker: Temperance.
sp.p: Then pray forbid monsieur serious contemplation not to bring his wild, stubborn, and useless opinions; for they make more disorder, and louder noise, and greater factions, than if all the dogs and bears in the town were set together by the ears, and more mischief comes thereby, than I can rectify.

div.stage: Enter liberty, and mademoiselle pleasure's gentleman-usher.

sp.speaker: Pleasure.
sp.p: Now liberty, you are a forerunner of visitants.

sp.speaker: Liberty.
sp.p: Yes madam, for there are the five sisters, the five senses, come to visit you.

sp.speaker: Pleasure.
sp.p: They are the troublesomest visitants that are; they are so extravagant, so impertinent, so various, and so humoursome, as I know not how to entertain them: but pray liberty usher them into the gallery where my pictures hang, drawn by the rarest and most famous masters; and let the room be sweetly perfumed, and bring a banquet of the most delicious and choicest drinks and meats, and let there be fine linen napkins, and spread all the floor over with downy carpets, and set soft cushions on the couches, and whilst they are there, let the music sound harmoniously, with soft strokes, pleasing notes, and gentle strains: and temperance, I desire you to order the rest of the entertainment, and let ease wait upon you: as for you, wanton and surfeit, I forbid you, as not to come into their company.

sp.speaker: Wanton.
sp.p: Always when my lady makes a great entertainment, we are forbid to appear.

sp.speaker: Surfet.
sp.p: Although my lady forbids me, yet the company never leaves until they have found me out, so that I am still at the end of the entertainment, like an epilogue to a play.

sp.speaker: Wanton.
sp.p: And I sometimes come in like a chorus.

div.head: Scene 22:
div.stage: Enter mademoiselle ambition, Bon' esprit, portrait, faction, monsieur heroic, monsieur Frisk.

sp.speaker: Portrait.
sp.p: O that I might have my wish!

sp.speaker: Ambition.
sp.p: What would you wish?

sp.speaker: Portrait.
sp.p: I would wish to be the only beauty.

sp.speaker: Heroick.
sp.p: And if I might have my wish, I would wish to conquer all the world, and then to divide it to the meritorious, and not to rule it myself: for I desire not the power, but the fame.

sp.speaker: Bon' esprit.
sp.p: And if I might have my wish, I would wish to be the supremest wit in nature.

sp.speaker: Frisk.
sp.p: You three are sympathetical in ambition; for one desires to incaptive all hearts with her beauty; the other desires to conquer all the world with his valour; the third desires to confute all mankind with her wit.

sp.speaker: Heroick.
sp.p: And what do you wish, mademoiselle ambition?

sp.speaker: Ambition.
sp.p: I wish I were destiny, to link you all three together.

sp.speaker: Faction.
sp.p: Come leave your wishing, and let us go to see the monster that is to be seen.

sp.speaker: Bon' esprit.
sp.p: The most monstrous creature I imagine, is a headless maid.

sp.speaker: Frisk.
sp.p: What is that, a devirginated maid?

sp.speaker: Bon' esprit.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Ambition.
sp.p: When she is devirginated, she is no maid.

sp.speaker: Bon' esprit.
sp.p: O yes; for as a wife is one that is married, a widow one that hath been married, so a maid is one that was never married, and a virgin is one that never knew man, and a headless maid is one that hath lost her virginity, and yet was never married.

sp.speaker: Faction.
sp.p: If a devirginated maid be a headless monster, in the world there are many headless monsters.

sp.speaker: Heroick.
sp.p: But the best of it is, lady, their monstrosity is invisible.

sp.speaker: Bon' esprit.
sp.p: You say true; but they are not monstrous in nature, but in vice, for they are transformed by their crimes.

sp.speaker: Ambition.
sp.p: So are drunkards.

sp.speaker: Bon' esprit.
sp.p: They are so; for all courtesans and drunkards are beasts: for though a drunkard is not a headless beast, yet he is a brainless beast.

sp.speaker: Portrait.
sp.p: But what monster is that you would have us to see?

sp.speaker: Faction.
sp.p: Why a woman with a hog's face.

sp.speaker: Bon' esprit.
sp.p: Then 'tis likely she hath a sow's disposition. But howsoever let us go.

div.head: Scene 23.
div.stage: Enter monsieur satyrical, and monsieur inquisitive.

sp.speaker: Inquisitive.
sp.p: One witty word, or saying from a fool, is, for the most part remembered, and often repeated, when from a wit it would be hardly taken notice of.

sp.speaker: Satyrical.
sp.p: There is reason for that: for wit is more remarkable from fools, than those that have natural wits.

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: Monsieur satyrical, I am come with a message from a company of fair young ladies; the message is this: they desire that you would do them the favour to come to them, to judge of a poem which they have made amongst themselves.

sp.speaker: Satyrical.
sp.p: Women make poems? burn them, burn them; let them make bonelace, let them make bonelace.

sp.speaker: Inquisitive.
sp.p: You are an unjust judge, to condemn their poems to the fire, before you have examined them.

sp.speaker: Satyrical.
sp.p: The best trial of a lady's wit is the fire; besides, the fire will supply that want of poetical heat which should make poems, which heat women's brains cannot suffer.

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: You are mistaken sir, and misinformed: for we women have as hot brains as any of the masculine sex of you all have.

sp.speaker: Satyrical.
sp.p: I grant your sex have an unnatural heat, which makes them all mad.

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: I think the ladies were mad when they sent me for you.

sp.speaker: Satyrical.
sp.p: No doubt of it, and you are mad for coming.

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: Your words will make me mad before I go away, although I came well-tempered hither: beshrew me my very bones do quiver in my flesh to hear you.

sp.speaker: Satyrical.
sp.p: If thy bones quiver so much as to shake, they will soon powder into dust: for age hath almost dissolved thee into ashes already, and time hath eaten off thy flesh, as crows do carrion.

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: Out upon thee satyr, a beastly man you are by my troth, and so I will deliver you to the ladies.

sp.speaker: Satyrical.
sp.p: You shall not deliver me to the ladies, I will deliver myself to death first.

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: Thou art so bad, death will refuse thee: but I will do your errand I'll warrant you, I'll set a mark upon you that shall disgrace you.

sp.speaker: Satyrical.
sp.p: Thou canst not set a fouler mark than thyself upon me, therefore come not near me.

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: Worse and worse, worse and worse. O that I were so young and fair, as my beauty might get me a champion to revenge my quarrel! But I will go back to the ladies, they are fair and young enough, as being in the spring of beauty, although I am in my autumnal years.

sp.speaker: Satyrical.
sp.p: Thou art in the midst of the winter of thine age, and the snow of time is fallen on thy head, and lies upon thy hair.

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: They that will not live until they are old, the proverb says, they must be hanged when they are young, and I hope it is your destiny.

div.head: Scene 24.
div.stage: Enter liberty, and wanton, and surfeit.

sp.speaker: Liberty.
sp.p: I am come to tell you, wanton and surfeit, that my lady is gone to receive the visit of monsieur tranquillities peace, who is come to see her, and old matron temperance is gone to wait upon her; wherefore you may go, for there is none left with the five senses but excess.

div.stage: They run out, then enters the five senses in antic dresses, to distinguish them, but they behave themselves as mad-merry, dancing about in couples, as hearing with wantonness, idle with scent, and excess with sigh, and surfeit with taste, and Touch dances alone by herself, and when they have danced, they go out.

div.head: Scene 25.
div.stage: Enter Bon' esprit, Superbe, faction, portrait, ambition.

sp.speaker: Faction.
sp.p: I wonder mother matron should stay so long.

sp.speaker: Portrait.
sp.p: I cannot guess at the reason.

sp.speaker: Bon' esprit.
sp.p: She might have delivered her message twice in this time.

div.stage: Enter mother matron; all the ladies speak at once.

sp.speaker: Ladies
sp.p: Mother matron, welcome, welcome, welcome: what news? what news?

sp.speaker: Faction.
sp.p: What says monsieur satyrical?

sp.speaker: Bon' esprit.
sp.p: Will he come?

sp.speaker: Portrait.
sp.p: Or will he not come? pray speak.

sp.speaker: Superbe.
sp.p: Are you dumb, mother matron?

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: Pray ladies give me some time to temper my passion; for if a house be set on fire, there is required sometime to quench it.

sp.speaker: Ambition.
sp.p: But some fires cannot be quenched.

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: Indeed my fire of anger is something of the nature of the unquenchable fire of hell, which endeavours to afflict the soul, as well as to torment the body.

sp.speaker: Superbe.
sp.p: Jove bless us, mother matron! Are you inflamed with hell-fire?

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: How should I be otherwise, when I have been tormented with a devil?

sp.speaker: Ambition.
sp.p: Jupiter keep us! What have you done, and with whom have you been?

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: Marry I have been with a cloven-tongued satyr, who is worse, far worse, than a cloven-footed devil.

sp.speaker: Bon' esprit.
sp.p: Is all this rage against monsieur satyrical?

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: Yes marry is it, and all too little, by reason it cannot hurt him.

sp.speaker: Faction.
sp.p: How hath he offended you?

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: As he hath offended you all, railed against you, most horribly railed against you: he says you are all mad, and hath condemned your poems to the fire, and your employment to the making of bonelace.

sp.speaker: Bon' esprit.
sp.p: Why these sayings of his do not offend me.

sp.speaker: Ambition.
sp.p: Nor me.

sp.speaker: Portrait.
sp.p: Nor me.

sp.speaker: Superbe.
sp.p: Nor me.

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: But if he had said you had been old, and ill-favoured, carrion for crows, dust and ashes for the grave, as he said to me, than you would have been as angry as I.

sp.speaker: Bon' esprit.
sp.p: No truly, I should have only laughed at it.

sp.speaker: Faction.
sp.p: By your favour, I should have been as angry as mother matron, if I had been as old as she; so I should have been concerned in the behalf of my age.

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: Marry come up, are you turned lady satyrical, to upbraid me with my age? Is this my reward for my jaunting and trotting up and down with your idle message to more idle persons, men that are mere jackstraws, flouting companions, railing detractors, such as are good for nothing but to put people together by the cars?

sp.speaker: Faction.
sp.p: By the effects it proves so, for you and I are very near falling out: but I thought you would have given me thanks for what I said, as taking your part, and not inveterates your spleen.

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: Can you expect I should give you thanks for calling me old? Can the report of age be acceptable to the effeminate sex? But lady, let me tell you, if you live you will be as old as I, and yet desire to be thought young: for although you were threescore, yet you would be very angry, nay in a furious rage, and take those to be your mortal enemies that should reckon you to be above one and twenty, for you will think yourself as beautiful as one of fifteen.

sp.speaker: Faction.
sp.p: I do not think so, although I believe our sex have good opinions of themselves, even to the last gasp; yet not so partial, as to imagine themselves as one of fifteen at threescore.

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: It is proved by all experience, that all mankind is self-conceited, especially the effeminate sex; and self-conceit doth cast a fair shadow on a foul face, and fills up the wrinkles of time with the paint of imagination.

sp.speaker: Portrait.
sp.p: But the eyes must be blind with age, or else they would see the wrinkles time hath made, in the despite of the paint of imagination.

sp.speaker: Superbe.
sp.p:
By your favour, self-conceit doth cause the eyes of sense to be like false glasses, that cast a youthful gloss, and a fair light, on a withered skin: for though the deep lines in the face cannot be smoothed, yet the lines, or species, in, or of the sight, may be drawn by self-conceit so small as not to be perceived: and were it not for the eyes of self-conceit, and the paint of imagination, as mother matron says, which preserves a good opinion
of ourselves, even to the time of our death, wherein all remembrance is buried, we should grow mad, as we grow old, for the loss of our youth and beauty.

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: I by my faith you would grow mad, did not conceit keep you in your right wits.

sp.speaker: Faction.
sp.p: The truth is, our sex grow melancholy, when our beauty decays.

sp.speaker: Portrait.
sp.p: I grow melancholy at the talking of it.

sp.speaker: Ambition.
sp.p: Let us speak of some other subject that is more pleasing than age, ruin, and death.

sp.speaker: Bon' esprit.
sp.p: Let us talk of monsieur satyrical again.

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: He is a worse subject to talk of than death.

sp.speaker: Bon' esprit.
sp.p: As bad as he is, you shall carry another message to him.

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: I will sooner carry a message to Pluto; for in my conscience he will use me more civilly, and will send you a more respectful answer than monsieur satyrical.

sp.speaker: Bon' esprit.
sp.p: Indeed I have heard that the devil would flatter; but I never heard that a satirical poet would flatter.

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: But a satirical poet will lie, and so will the devil; and therefore talk no more of them, but leave them together.

div.head: Scene 26.

sp.speaker: Pleasure.
sp.p: O temperance, I am discredited for ever, the ladies the senses are all sick: what shall I do?

sp.speaker: Temperance.
sp.p: You must send for some doctors.

sp.speaker: Pleasure.
sp.p: What doctors shall I send for?

sp.speaker: Temperance.
sp.p: Why old father time, he hath practised long, and hath great experience; then there is rest and sleep, two very good and safe doctors.

sp.speaker: Pleasure.
sp.p: Send ease presently to fetch them, bid her make haste.

div.stage: Enter the five senses, as being very sick, yet touch seems not so sick as melancholy: they all pass silently over the stage.

sp.speaker: Pleasure.
sp.p: Temperance, are the doctors come?

sp.speaker: Temperance.
sp.p: Yes, and gone again.

sp.speaker: Pleasure.
sp.p: And what have they prescribed?

sp.speaker: Temperance.
sp.p: Abstinence.

sp.speaker: Pleasure.
sp.p: And will that cure them?

sp.speaker: Temperance.
sp.p: They say it will prove a perfect cure: probatum est.

sp.speaker: Pleasure.
sp.p: The next act I do, shall be to turn away wanton, idle, excess, and surfeit.

sp.speaker: Temperance.
sp.p: You will hardly get them out of your service, although you should beat them out.

div.head: Scene 27.
div.stage: Enter mademoiselle ambition, and her waiting-woman.

sp.speaker: Woman.
sp.p: Madam, methinks monsieur vainglorious is a very proper man, and would be a fit match for your ladyship.

sp.speaker: Ambition.
sp.p: Let me tell you, I will never marry a man whose soul hath vacuum; but that man I would marry, should have a soul filled with nature's best extractions; his head the cabinet of nature's wisest counsels, and curiousest fancies; his heart the treasury of nature's purest, currentest, and heroic virtue: for if ever I marry, I will have a husband that is able to govern kingdoms, to marshal armies, to fight battles, and conquer nations; and not a self-conceited fool, or fantastical gallant, such as speaks ranting words, wears slanting clothes, walks with a proud garb, looks with a disdainful countenance, courts mistresses, loves flatteries, hates superiors, and scorns inferiors, keeps a greater retinue than his revenue will maintain, who like moths, eat through the cloth of his estate, and he like another fly, plays so long in his vainglorious flame, until he is consumed therein, spending with an open purse, and prodigal vanity, and yet receives with a covetous hand: so vanity flies and flutters about in the heat of prosperity, and dies in the winter of adversity. No, I will have a husband, if ever I have any, whose mind is settled like the centre, which can neither rise nor fall with good or bad fortune; and not a little soul in a narrow heart, and witless brain.

div.head: Scene 28.
div.stage: Enter monsieur satyrical, and another gentleman.

sp.speaker: Gentlem.
sp.p: Sir, I desire you will pardon me; but I am commanded to bring you here a challenge.

sp.speaker: Satyrical.
sp.p: Are you the second, sir?

sp.speaker: Gentleman
sp.p: No sir.

sp.speaker: Satyrical.
sp.p: Are you a pimp, sir?

sp.speaker: Gentleman
sp.p: I scorn your base words, for I am a gentleman.

sp.speaker: Satyrical.
sp.p: Many a gentleman scorns base words, but not base actions.

sp.speaker: Gentleman
sp.p: I scorn both base words, and base actions.

sp.speaker: Satyrical.
sp.p: It doth not seem so by the challenge you have brought.

sp.speaker: Gentleman
sp.p: Why, what is the challenge?

sp.speaker: Satyrical.
sp.p: The challenge is from a woman, and I will read it to you.

body.l: I challenge you, and am resolved to fight,
Not in the field of Mars, as champion knight,
Nor in the court of Venus will I be,
But to the lists of Mercury challenge thee:
Where all the muses will spectators sit,
To judge which is the greatest victor of wit.
The weapons which we fight with must be words,
For I a woman am, not used to swords:
Custom and education leaves us bare
To nature's arms, the arms of death we fear.

sp.speaker: Satyrical.
sp.p: These two last lines make you a pimp, sir.

sp.speaker: Gentleman
sp.p: I must be contended, for there is no revenge to be taken against ladies: but mother matron had been a more properer messenger than I for this challenge.

sp.speaker: Satyrical.
sp.p: I shall send my answer by a more inferior person than you are, and so shall take my leave for this time.

sp.speaker: Gentleman
sp.p: Your servant.

div.head: Scene 29.
div.stage: Enter mademoiselle Bon' esprit, portrait, faction, ambition, Superbe.

sp.speaker: Faction.
sp.p: All poets and musicians are mad, more or less: for madness is caused by a distemper of the brain, like as the pulse, which beats quicker than the natural motion.

sp.speaker: Bon' esprit.
sp.p: You mistake madness; for madness is not caused by the quickness of motion, but by the irregularity of the motion: and as for poetical and musical motions, although they are quick, yet they keep time, time and order, when those motions that cause madness do not: but the quick-moving brains of poets are caused by their lively and elevated spirits, which are active and industrious, always creating for delight or profit, as verses, fancies, scenes, sonnets, or inventing arts: and if you account these ingenious and divine spirits to be mad, I shall desire to be mad too, as they are.

sp.speaker: Faction.
sp.p: But some spirits are so quick, that they out run all invention.

sp.speaker: Bon' esprit.
sp.p:
Those are neither the spirits of poets nor musicians; not but that poets and musicians may be mad as other men, but their madness is not
caused by the poetical and harmonical spirits, but some other defects of the brain, or distemper of the spirits; but there are many mad, that are so far from poetical fancies, or musical skill, or inventions, as they can neither conceive the one, or learn the other, or understand either; but music and poetry have oft-times cured madness, and certainly are the best and most excellent physicians for that disease: for though madness is but one and the same disease, as madness, yet the causes and effects are divers.

sp.speaker: Superbe.
sp.p: A fever in the brain causeth madness.

sp.speaker: Bon' esprit.
sp.p: It rather causeth madness to have outrage: effects; but a cold brain may be mad: but it is neither heat nor cold that causeth madness, but the irregularity of the spirits.

sp.speaker: Ambition.
sp.p: But heat and cold may cause the irregularity of the spirits: for as cold livers make the veins like standing ponds, which putrifies the blood for want of motion; so very cold brains may be like snow or ice, to obstruct or bind the spirits, hindering the regular motions.

sp.speaker: Bon' esprit.
sp.p: You say right, and that is a stupid madness: and as a hot liver may boil and inflame the blood, so hot brains may inflame the spirits, causing combustious motions, as thundering, which is a raging madness.

sp.speaker: Censure.
sp.p: Who is raging-mad?

sp.speaker: Faction.
sp.p: A despairing lover.

sp.speaker: Censure.
sp.p: Hang him in his mistress frowns, or strangle him in the cords of her cruelty.

sp.speaker: Superbe.
sp.p: Would you be served so?

sp.speaker: Censure.
sp.p: Yes, when I am a mad lover: for I had rather die than be in love with a hard-hearted mistress; for of the two I had rather embrace death than court her, in which courtship I should be transformed, or metamorphosed into many several things: as I should be a river of lovers tears, a ventiduct of lovers sighs, an aquaduct of lovers griefs, and a chilling grotto of lovers fears; and rather than I would endure these transformations, I would be well contended to be annihilated.

sp.speaker: Ambition.
sp.p: O fie, had you rather be nothing than a lover?

sp.speaker: Censure.
sp.p: I had rather be nothing, than a thing worse than nothing.
