sp.speaker: Faction.
sp.p: Well, I hope to see you a desperate lover at one time or other.

sp.speaker: Censure.
sp.p: I hope not, for I have no cause to fear: for my mind cannot be persuaded by my fancy, or forced by my appetites, nor betrayed by my senses; for reason governs my brain, temperance rules my appetites, prudence guards my senses, and fortitude keeps the possession and fort of my heart.

sp.speaker: Faction.
sp.p: Love will unthrone reason, corrupt temperance, bribe prudence, and bear fortitude out of the fort of your heart.

sp.speaker: Censure.
sp.p: For fear of that I will leave you, ladies.

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: News; news, monsieur satyrical hath vouchsafed to return you an answer to your challenge.

sp.speaker: Bon' esprit.
sp.p: Who brought it?

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: A scrubbed fellow in a threadbare cloak, the rest of the ladies say. Read it, read it, mademoiselle Bon' esprit.
sp.l: Lady, you challenged me in arms to fight,
Appoint the place, the best time is at night
For natural duellers; yet I submit,
And shall obey to what hour you think fit:
I am content my health for to engage,
And venture life to satisfy your rage.
I am no coward, I am not afraid
To fight a duel with a young fair maid,
Although old mother matron she should be
Your second, for the judge what she doth see.

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: He makes me the scurvy burden of his more scurvy verse, and scurrilous answer: but I hope this answer of his to your challenge, will inveterate your spleen as much as his upbraiding my age did mine.

sp.speaker: Bon' esprit.
sp.p: I have not such reason to be so concerned as you are; for I am honest, though you are old.

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: May the infamy of vice wither the blossoms of youth, as age doth the flowers of beauty, that there may be an equal return of reproach.

sp.speaker: Bon' esprit.
sp.p: Indeed there is some reciprocalness in vice and age.

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: No, vice and youth are reciprocal.

sp.speaker: Ambition.
sp.p: But I see no reciprocalness betwixt love and monsieur satyrical.

sp.speaker: Bon' esprit.
sp.p: I make no doubt but to bring monsieur satyrical into Cupid's snare.

sp.speaker: Faction.
sp.p: You may sooner bring yourself into Vulcan's net.

sp.speaker: Bon' esprit.
sp.p: Well, mark the end and success.

sp.speaker: Superbe.
sp.p: Nay, rather we shall mark the endless folly.

div.head: Scene 30.
div.stage: Enter mademoiselle pleasure, and monsieur vainglorious.

sp.speaker: Vainglorious.
sp.p: Lady Pleasure, you are the sweetest young lady in the world, and the only delight in life.

sp.speaker: Pleasure.
sp.p: O sir, you give a wooer's sentence, and self-love hath bribed your judgement: for most speak partially, according to their affections, and not according to truth.

sp.speaker: Vain-glor
sp.p: Truth is a prating, preaching, tattling, twattling gossip, and tells many times that which would be better concealed.

sp.speaker: Pleasure.
sp.p: Truth is the eye of knowledge, which brings men out of ignorance: it is the scale of justice, the sword of execution, the reward of merit: it is the bond of propriety, and the seal of honesty.

sp.speaker: Vain-glor
sp.p: Truth is a tyrant, condemning more than she saves.

sp.speaker: Pleasure.
sp.p: She condemns none but fools, knaves, cowards, irreligious, licentious, and vainglorious persons, to be unworthy, base, false, and wicked.

sp.speaker: Vainglorious.
sp.p: She condemns pleasure; for truly there is no such thing as pleasure.

sp.speaker: Satyrical.
sp.p:
I must marry, or bury succession in my grave; but it's dangerous, very dangerous. O nature, nature, hadst thou no other way to create a man, unless thou madest a woman! But if thou wert forced by the fates to make that sex, yet thou hadst liberty to make her of a constant mind; but thou art inconstant thyself, as being of female kind: but since I must marry, discretion shall make the choice, which will choose virtue before wealth, wit before beauty, breeding before birth; if she hath virtue, she will be chaste; if she hath wit, she will be conversable, if she hath good breeding, she will be modest and well-behaved. But where is that woman that is virtuously chaste, wittily conversable, and modestly-behaved? If any woman be thus, as I would have her, it is mademoiselle Bon' esprit, she seems to have a noble soul by her honourable actions, which women, for the most part, are so far from, as they seem, for the most part, to have no souls at all, by their mean and petty actions: also she hath a supernatural wit, I mean supernatural, as being a woman; and her wit is not only ingenious, but judicious, by which she will set a value on subjects of merit and worth, and despise those that are base; when fools know not how to prize the best, but choose that is bad, not knowing what is good, so walk in errors ways, which leads unto dishonour; but she, having wit and honour, knows the benefit of honesty so well, as she will be chaste for her own sake, were it not for her husbands. But I most satirically have translated her sweet and harmless mirth, which was presented in her elevated verse into a wanton interpretation. Diana, thou goddess of chastity, pardon me! But stay thoughts, whither wander you? let me examine you before you pass any farther, as whether or no you are not led by the bowstring of Cupid, or the girdle of Venus, into the foul paths of vain desires, and deluding beauty, to the labyrinth of destruction, there to be kept and incaptivated by the entanglements and subtle windings, and turnings, and various passages of amorous love? But a strict examination requires time, and a just
judge decides not a cause without debate; therefore I will have another contemplation of consideration, before I address my suit, or make known my desires.

div.head: Scene 32.
div.stage: Enter mademoiselle ambition, and monsieur vain glorious.

sp.speaker: Vain-glor.
sp.p: Madam, why should you refuse me?

sp.speaker: Ambition.
sp.p: Because I cannot love.

sp.speaker: Vain-glor
sp.p: Not love me? why I am valiant, wise, witty, honest, generous, and handsome: and where will you find a man where all these excellencies do meet in one?

sp.speaker: Ambition.
sp.p: Now you have bragged of yourself, I will plainly prove to you, that you are neither perfectly valiant, nor wise, nor witty, nor generous, nor truly honest.

sp.speaker: Vain-glor
sp.p: You cannot.

sp.speaker: Ambition.
sp.p: I can: and first for valour. Have you gone to the wars, and fought? why, millions do the like, and a poor common soldier will venture for sixpence on that which a vain cavalier will hardly do to gain an immortal fame: or peradventure you have fought duels, why every drunkard will do as much, who in their drink they not reason to consider valour, which is only to fight for the sake of honour; but most commonly duels are fought through anger, or fear, or scorn, or revenge, or the like, which is not true valour, but they fight rather like beasts than men, as with force, fury, or appetite, caused by natural antipathies, or through the heat of the blood, or desires or dislikes of the senses: whereas true valour is just, temperate, patient, prudent, and is the heroic part, or virtue of the soul: and to be valiant, is to fight for the right of truth, and the defence of innocency, without partiality, covetousness, or ambition: also to prove yourself valiant, have you received misfortunes with patience, and suffered torments with fortitude? Have you forgiven your enemies, or spared a bloody execution for humanity's sake, or released rich prisoners without ransom, and poor without slavery? Have you heard yourself slandered with patience, justified your wrongs with temperance, fought your enemies without anger, maintained your honour without vainglory, than you are valiant.

And for wisdom, what do you call wisdom? to speak hebrew, Greek, and Latin, and not understand them? or to understand them, and cannot speak them? Or to cite dead authors? Or to repeat their learned opinions? Or to make Sophisterian disputes? Or to speak Latin sentences? Or to tell storeys out of histories? Or to write several hands? Or to spell with true orthography? Or to talk of the sciences, but study none? Or to talk of morality, but practice none? This you may call learned, but not wisdom. But to be wise, have you settled a kingdom in peace, and put it in order, when it was embroiled with civil wars, or ensnared with confused and entangled laws? Or have you appeased a mutinous and half-starved army? Have you led an army with order, pitched a field with art,
fought a battle with prudence, or have made a safe and honourable retreat? Or have you been so provident, as to relieve famine with fore-stored provisions? Or to prevent misfortunes with foresight? Or have you distinguished a cause clearly, or given an upright judgement? Or have you delivered judicious counsel, and given seasonable and suitable admonitions? Have you composed a commonwealth, or made profitable laws to uphold a commonwealth? Have you defended a commonwealth from enemies, or purged a commonwealth from factions? Have you made officers worthy of employments, magistrates able to govern, soldiers skilful to command? Have you fitly matched men and business, and offices with men? Have you employed the idle, and given light to the ignorant? Have you discharged a commonwealth of superfluity, or superfluous commodities, and brought in those which are more useful, such as they have wanted? Have you manured a barren country, or enriched a poor kingdom? Have you made honest associates, faithful agreements, and safe traffics? Then you may think yourself wise, and be silent; for the actions will proclaim it.

Also what do you call wit? Imitating extravagancies like a jackanapes, or a buffoon, to extort the countenance with making wry faces? Or with much laughter to show the teeth, which perchance are all rotten in the head? Or foolishly to divulge the infirmities of particular persons in an open assembly? Or putting innocency or youth out of countenance? Or to disturb the serious with idle sports? Or disorder the wise with foolish and rude jests? Or do you all wit affected dresses, affected garbs, affected countenances, or vain-strained compliments, or useless words, or senseless speeches, or cross answers, or impertinent questions? But for your wit, hath your fame flown beyond Euripides, Homer, or Ovid, your descriptions beyond Horace, or your verse beyond Virgil? Have you oratory to equal the orators of Athens, Lacedæmonians, or Rome? or have you devised any ingenious inventions, or produced any profitable arts, or found out any new sciences? Then you are witty.

Likewise what do you call honesty? to live luxuriously to yourself, not meddling, nor intermingling yourself and home-affairs with the public affairs of the world? To keep open house at Christmas? To give your scraps to the poor? To pay wages duly, debts justly, taxes quietly? To kiss your maids privately? And although all this is good and commendable, but the kissing of your maids, yet it is not enough to make a perfect honest man: but to be perfectly honest, have you tempered your insatiable appetite with abstinency, moderated your violated passions with reason, governed your unruly actions with prudence? Have you not exacted unjustly, judged partially, accused falsely, betrayed treacherously, kept wrongfully, took forcibly? but have you advanced virtues, defended the innocent? Have you witnessed for truth, pleaded for right, and stood for the defenceless? Then you are perfectly honest.

Also what do you call generosity? To give a present to a lewd mistress? To bribe a corrupted judge? Or fee a subtle lawyer? Or feast the vain courtiers? Or maintain sycophants and flatterers? Or bail a just arrest? Or to be bound for the deboist? Or to give ladies collations? Or to lend or give idle drunken fellows money? Or to give when you think to hear of it again? This is prodigality, not generosity. But to be generous, have you set your prisoner free, ransomed the captives, or bought off the chains
of the galley-slaves? Have you maintained young orphans, or helped poor widows? Have you cheered the aged, nourished the hungry, succoured the infirm, relieved the distressed, comforted the sorrowful, and guided the ignorant? Or have you upholden an ancient family from sinking? Then you are generous.

As for your person, the more handsome and beautiful you are, the more effeminate you seem. But to conclude, that man that hath a narrow heart, and a mean soul, that only seeks his own delights, which all vainglorious persons do, I will not marry: for noble ambition hath a heart, whose veins with bounty flow, and wears her life only for honour's use and virtues need.

div.head: Scene 33.
div.stage: Enter grave temperance, Superbe, Bon' esprit, faction, portrait.

sp.speaker: Temperance.
sp.p: There is no behaviour so inconvenient, or so unfitting a woman, especially a young beautiful lady, as to be familiar: for that gives way and liberty for men to be rude and uncivil.

sp.speaker: Portrait.
sp.p: Why how would you have a young lady to behave herself?

sp.speaker: Temperance.
sp.p: Modestly, reservedly, and civilly, which behaviour will keep men in order, and at a distance.

sp.speaker: Superbe.
sp.p: To seem very modest, is to appear simple; to be much reserved, is to be formal, which is only fit for state-ladies; to be very civil, is to be too humble, and appears mean, and only fit for country wives.

sp.speaker: Temperance.
sp.p: No lady, for those that give no respect, will receive none; but those that are civil to others, others will be civil to them: for they will be ashamed to be rude to those that are civil: and as for gravity, it puts boldness out of countenance, and modesty quenches unlawful desires, converting the beholders to purity, love, and esteem.

sp.speaker: Faction.
sp.p: There is no behaviour like to the French mode, to be careless and free, to discourse in raillery.

sp.speaker: Temperance.
sp.p: To be careless, is to be rude; to be free, is to be wanton; to raillery, is to reproach under the protection of wit, it is a reproachful wit, and a wit of reproach.

sp.speaker: Bon' esprit.
sp.p: All wit is commendable.

sp.speaker: Temperance.
sp.p: No lady, a jester's wit is not fit for a grave judge, or a great prince, he may keep a fool, or make a fool to make him merry, and to laugh at their jests and gestures, but not to be a buffoon or jester himself.

sp.speaker: Bon' esprit.
sp.p:
Let me advise and counsel you, temperance, which is, to condemn
no kind of wit, but especially a mode-wit, lest you should be accounted a foolish judge.

sp.speaker: Temperance.
sp.p: Let me tell you, they will be the greatest fools that judge the judge.

sp.speaker: Satyrical.
sp.p: I am resolved, yet being a criminal, how to address my suit, I am in doubt: to ask pardon for my faults, were to make my faults seem greater than they are; to excuse them, were to make my judgement seem weaker than I think it is; to justify them, were to condemn her. Well, I will neither ask pardon, nor make excuse, nor yet justify them; but in plain language declare my pure affections, honest desires, and honourable requests; if she believes the first, approves the third, and consents to the second, I hope to be happy, if not, I must be content: for it is a folly to mourn, when it brings no remedy.

div.head: Scene 35.
div.stage: Enter Bon' esprit, portrait, faction, ambition, Superbe, mother matron,

sp.speaker: Faction.
sp.p: The lady variety, now she is a widow, she tricks and dresses up herself in her mourning, and is more fond of the company of men, than we that are maids.

sp.speaker: Bon' esprit.
sp.p: 'Tis a sign she knows by experience that the masculine sex are better, and more pleasurable company than any of her own sex, which maids do not know, by reason they are for the most part restrained.

sp.speaker: Portrait.
sp.p: Why should you find fault with widows, when married wives endeavour by all the arts they can to get the company of men, and do strive by enticements to allure them to courtships, as much as widows or maids to lawful and honest marriage?

sp.speaker: Ambition.
sp.p: One would think that married women, by their neglect and disrespect to their husbands, they loved not the company of men.

sp.speaker: Superbe.
sp.p: They may love the company of men, though not the company of one man, as their husbands.

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: Come, come, ladies, maids are always spiteful to married women, because they be preferred in marriage before them, and are jealous of widows, for fear that they should get their servants and suitors from them.

sp.speaker: Faction.
sp.p:
I should sooner be jealous of a widow, than spiteful to a married wife: for most wives are in a condition to be pitied rather than envied;
but widows have such a magnetic power, as one widow will draw away the servants and suitors from a dozen maids.

sp.speaker: Bon' esprit.
sp.p: Indeed widows are very prevalent; for a poor widow shall have more suitors, and better choice, than a rich maid, and an ill-favoured widow, than a handsome maid, an old widow, than a young virgin.

sp.speaker: Ambition.
sp.p: I wonder at it.

sp.speaker: Faction.
sp.p: Why should you wonder at it? since they know the humours, weaknesses, and strengths of men, better than maids do, by which they know how to work and draw them to their bent and design.

sp.speaker: Bon' esprit.
sp.p: No, that's not the cause.

sp.speaker: Faction.
sp.p: What's the cause then?

sp.speaker: Bon' esprit.
sp.p: Why men think widows wiser than maids, as being more known and experienced.

sp.speaker: Portrait.
sp.p: Indeed they have more knowledge than maids, or else they have very ill luck.

sp.speaker: Ambition.
sp.p: Why, maids are more desirous to marry widowers than bachelors.

sp.speaker: Superbe.
sp.p: What is the reason of that?

sp.speaker: Bon' esprit.
sp.p: I know not, except it be the former reason.

sp.speaker: Faction.
sp.p: No, no, it is because it is said that widowers love their second wives better than the first.

sp.speaker: Portrait.
sp.p: And what their third wife?

sp.speaker: Faction.
sp.p: I suppose love increaseth with the number.

sp.speaker: Ambition.
sp.p: But women, 'tis said, love their first husband better than the second.

sp.speaker: Superbe.
sp.p: That's only an excuse to marry a third, and so a fourth husband.

sp.speaker: Bon' esprit.
sp.p: Indeed death and Hymen are great friends to widows and widowers: for if once a woman buries her husband, or a man his wife, they never leave marrying and burying, until they have had five or six husband and wives.

sp.speaker: Faction.
sp.p: If it were always so, I would I had been married, and had buried my husband; oh what a gossipping life should I have had! Gossipping at my husband's funerals, and gossipping at my married nuptials, besides the pleasure of being wooed.

sp.speaker: Bon' esprit.
sp.p: But you would have more trouble and vexation in the time between your marriage-day and your husband's death, than pleasure betwixt your husband's death and marriage-day.

sp.speaker: Faction.
sp.p: O no: for I suppose if death be a friend, he will take away every husband as soon as that time is past they call honey-month.

sp.speaker: Inquisitive.
sp.p: Ladies, I will tell you news.

sp.speaker: Portrait.
sp.p: What news?

sp.speaker: Inquisitive.
sp.p: The young widow, the lady variety, hath the small pox.

sp.speaker: Faction.
sp.p: That's no news; for all sorts of diseases are too frequent to be news; if they were, it would be happy for all animal creatures, if diseases were strangers.

sp.speaker: Inquisitive.
sp.p: But it is news that she should have them.

sp.speaker: Faction.
sp.p:
It is in respect of a new face, or otherwise not: for all mankind
in these parts of the world have that disease at one time or other, if they live to't.

sp.speaker: Inquisitive.
sp.p: Truly I pity her.

sp.speaker: Ambition.
sp.p: I hope she is not in such a condition to be pitied: for pity is a kin to scorn, as near as cousin-germans, for reproach and shame are brother and sister, and scorn is the son of reproach, and pity is the daughter of shame: but although the small pox may set marks of deformity, they set none of dishonour; they only mark the body, not the soul; and that is only to be accounted shame, and to be ashamed of, as the infirmities of the soul, for which they may be pitied.

sp.speaker: Inquisitive.
sp.p: That deserves scorn.

sp.speaker: Ambition.
sp.p: Baseness only deserves scorn, and not infirmities, loss, or misfortunes; but there is a difference betwixt infirmities, loss, misfortunes, baseness, and wickedness. Infirmities proceed directly from nature, Loss from possession, misfortunes from interpositions, baseness from that creature called man, and wickedness from devils: the first is caused by the carelessness of nature, the second by the lack of power, the third by the necessity of fate, the fourth by the corruption of man, the last by the persuasion and temptation of the devil. The first, second, and third are not to be avoided, the fourth not to be practised, the fifth not to be followed nor fostered. The first is to be pitied, the second to be grieved for, the third to be lamented for, the fourth to be scorned, and the fifth to be hated and abhorred. Thus we may grieve for the loss of her beauty, but not pity her, having no natural defect in the soul, which is the understanding, and the rational part.

sp.speaker: Inquisitive.
sp.p: But sickness is a natural defect.

sp.speaker: Ambition.
sp.p: No, sickness is no more a natural defect, than time, or death, life, or growth: for they are only natural effects, but not natural defects.

div.head: Scene 36.
div.stage: Enter mademoiselle pleasure, wanton, surfeit, idle, excess, her maids: they all weep.

sp.speaker: All speak.
sp.p: Pray turn us not out of your service for one fault.

sp.speaker: Pleasure.
sp.p: Why you are the ground wherein all mischief is sown, and whereon all vice grows; besides, you are the only bawds for adultery.

sp.speaker: Wanton.
sp.p: No indeed, the chief bawds to adultery, are public meetings of all kinds, either divine, customary, triumphant, or recreative: also bravery, whether ceremonious gallantry, or magnificency: likewise beauty, wit, diligence, observance, and rich presents: besides jealousy and covetousness.

sp.speaker: Pleasure.
sp.p: No, wanton, it is your glancing eyes, simpering countenance, and toyish tricks.

sp.speaker: Wanton.
sp.p:
Truly madam, idle and I are fitter to make wenches than bawds,
'tis your ladyship that is the lady of pleasure, which persuades more to adultery than we poor harmless creatures.

sp.speaker: Pleasure.
sp.p: Go get you out of my house, for I will not keep such bold rude wenches as you are.

sp.speaker: Temperance.
sp.p: Pray madam pardon them for this time.

div.head: Scene 37.
div.stage: Enter mademoiselle ambition, Superbe, faction, pleasure, portrait, monsieur heroic, monsieur tranquillities peace, monsieur Frisk, monsieur censure, monsieur inquisitive.

sp.speaker: Pleasure.
sp.p: How shall we pass our time today?

sp.speaker: Tranquill. Peace.
sp.p: For us men we cannot pass our time better, or more pleasanter, than in the company of fair young ladies.

sp.speaker: Ambition.
sp.p: To avoid tedious compliments and discourses to particular cars, or the confusion of many tongues speaking at once, let us sit and discourse in dialogues.

sp.speaker: Heroick.
sp.p: Agreed; but shall we discourse in rhyme or in prose?

sp.speaker: Superbe.
sp.p: In rhymes by any means: for rhymes many times hide and obscure that nonsense that would be discovered in prose.

sp.speaker: Vain-glor
sp.p: Then it seems rhyme is a veil to cover the face of nonsense.

sp.speaker: Superbe.
sp.p: They are so: for one can never discover an ill poem, until the rhymes be dissolved into prose, which shows whether there be sense, reason, wit, or fancy in them.

sp.speaker: Ambition.
sp.p: But to be turned into prose, the poems will lose the elegance of the style, and the eloquence of the language.

sp.speaker: Faction.
sp.p: Why, if a man should lose his hat and feather, and be stripped of a fine and gay suit of clothes, he would neither have the less brain nor blood, nor soul, nor body, beauty nor shape; and though gay and glorious apparel may allure the eyes of a young lady, or a novice gentleman, or may draw the ignorant vulgar to admiration, and so to an esteem and respect; yet those that have clear understandings, solid judgements, quick wits, and knowing wisdoms, will be so far from admiring the man for the sake of his gay clothes, or esteeming him for his glorious attire, as they will be apt to condemn him as a vain man.

sp.speaker: Inquisitive.
sp.p: Then you reject the clothing of poems in fine language.

sp.speaker: Faction.
sp.p: No; but I despise those poems that have nothing but language and rhymes.

sp.speaker: Frisk.
sp.p: Then it is a folly to write in verse, if rhymes be not accounted of.

sp.speaker: Pleasure.
sp.p: Verse is to be accounted of for the sake of numbers, which is harmonious; yet neither harmonious numbers, nor chiming rhymes, nor gay rhetoric, is reason, wit, nor fancy, which is the ground, body, or soul of a good poem.

sp.speaker: Censure.
sp.p: Yet no poem is esteemed, but condemned, that is not in gay and new-fashioned clothing.

sp.speaker: Ambition.
sp.p:
Then Chaucer's poems, which are in plain and old-fashioned
garments, which is language, is to be despised, and his wit condemned; but certainly Chaucer's witty poems, and lively descriptions, in despite of their old language, as they have lasted in great esteem and admiration these three hundred years, so they may do eternally amongst the wise in every age.

sp.speaker: Heroick.
sp.p: Gentlemen, leave off your disputes, for the ladies will be too hard for us: for they are always conquerors in peace and war, both in the schools and in the fields, in the city and in the court.

sp.speaker: Portrait.
sp.p: Pray leave off this particular dispute, and let us discourse in general.

sp.speaker: Tranquill. Peace.
sp.p: Agreed.

sp.speaker: Superbe.
sp.p: Begin.

sp.speaker: Inquisitive.
sp.p: Who shall begin?

sp.speaker: Faction.
sp.p: I will begin; for a woman's tongue hath privilege and preeminency in the first place.

sp.speaker: Faction.
sp.p: Old brains are like to barren ground,

sp.speaker: Censure.
sp.p: Or like a wilderness forlorn,

sp.speaker: Portrait.
sp.p: Or like cracked bells that have no sound,

sp.speaker: Tranquill. Peace.
sp.p: Or like a child abortive born:

sp.speaker: Ambition.
sp.p: For time the fire of wit puts out,

sp.speaker: Heroick.
sp.p: And fills the brain with vapour cold,

sp.speaker: Superbe.
sp.p: And quenches fancy without doubt,

sp.speaker: Vain-glor
sp.p: For wit is feeble when 'tis old.

sp.speaker: Portrait.
sp.p: Wit neither fails, weakens, decays, nor dies,

sp.speaker: Inquisitive.
sp.p: Though bred and born, as other creatures are,

sp.speaker: Faction.
sp.p: Only the brain, the womb wherein it lies:

sp.speaker: Censure.
sp.p: But when 'tis born, fame nurses it with care,

sp.speaker: Frisk.
sp.p: And to eternity doth it prefer.

sp.speaker: Pleasure.
sp.p: Wit makes the brain sick when it breeding is,

sp.speaker: Tranquill.
sp.p: And painful throws before, and at its birth;

sp.speaker: Ambition.
sp.p: But when 'tis born, if good, a comfort 'tis,

sp.speaker: Heroick.
sp.p: The parent poetry creates with mirth,

sp.speaker: Superbe.
sp.p: He joys to see his issue fairly spring,

sp.speaker: Vain-glor
sp.p: And hopes with time in numbers may increase,

sp.speaker: Portrait.
sp.p: And being multiplied may honours bring,

sp.speaker: Frisk.
sp.p: As a posterity that never cease.

sp.speaker: Faction.
sp.p: Wit, the issue, and offspring of the soul,

sp.speaker: Censure
sp.p: From which the nature sublimely is divine,

sp.speaker: Pleasure.
sp.p: Dimensions hath, and parts, yet in the whole,

sp.speaker: Tranquill.
sp.p: United is, of breaches there's no sign.

sp.speaker: Ambition.
sp.p: Wit, like the soul is, which nobody hath,

sp.speaker: Heroick.
sp.p: No latitude, yet hath a perfect form,

sp.speaker: Superbe.
sp.p: Yet flies all several ways, yet keeps a path,

sp.speaker: Vain-glor
sp.p: A path of sense, which never turns therefrom.

sp.speaker: Portrait.
sp.p: But wondrous strange, and monstrous is wit,

sp.speaker: Inquisitive.
sp.p: That all contrarieties in it do dwell:

sp.speaker: Faction.
sp.p: For it all shapes, employments, humours fit,

sp.speaker: Censure.
sp.p: Like beasts, men, gods, or terrible devils in hell.

sp.speaker: Temperance.
sp.p: O fie, oh fie, this discourse is like dancing the hay, or dancing a Scotch gig, which will put you out of breath straight.

sp.speaker: Faction.
sp.p: You would have us discourse in the measure of a Spanish pavin.

sp.speaker: Temperance.
sp.p: No, but the measure of a French galliard would do very well.

sp.speaker: Censure.
sp.p: For my part, lady, I like jigs best, and therefore, if you please, begin another gig.

sp.speaker: Faction.
sp.p: The spring is dressed in buds and blossoms sweet:

sp.speaker: Censure.
sp.p: The summer laughs until her cheeks look red,

sp.speaker: Pleasure.
sp.p: The plenteous autumn warm under our feet.

sp.speaker: Tranquill. Peace.
sp.p: The winter shaking cold, is almost dead.

sp.speaker: All speak.
sp.p: Go on with the twelve months.

sp.speaker: Ambition.
sp.p: Fierce furious march comes in with bent brows,

sp.speaker: Heroick.
sp.p: Commanding storms and tempests to arise,

sp.speaker: Superbe.
sp.p: Beating the trees and clouds, as if it meant

sp.speaker: Vain-glory.
sp.p: To make them subject to his tyrannies.

sp.speaker: Portrait.
sp.p: Then follows April, weeping for her buds,

sp.speaker: Frisk.
sp.p: For fear rude march had all her young destroyed;

sp.speaker: Faction.
sp.p: But when she thought her tears might rise to floods,

sp.speaker: Censure.
sp.p: With sunbeams dried her eyes, his heat her joyed.

sp.speaker: Pleasure.
sp.p: Then wanton may came full of amorous sports,

sp.speaker: Tranquill. Peace.
sp.p: Decking herself with gawdy colours gay,

sp.speaker: Ambition.
sp.p: And entertaining lovers of all sorts,

sp.speaker: Heroick.
sp.p: In pleasure she doth pass her time a way.

sp.speaker: Superbe.
sp.p: Then enters June with fair and full fat face,

sp.speaker: Vain-glor
sp.p: Her eyes are bright and clear as the noon-sun,

sp.speaker: Portrait.
sp.p: And in her carriage hath a majestic grace,

sp.speaker: Inquisitive.
sp.p: In equinoctial pace she walks, not run.

sp.speaker: Faction.
sp.p: But july's sultry hot, ambitious proud,

sp.speaker: Censure.
sp.p: And in a fiery chariot she doth ride,

sp.speaker: Pleasure.
sp.p: When angry is, she thundering speaks aloud,

sp.speaker: Tranquill. Peace.
sp.p: Shoots lightning through the clouds on every side.

div.stage: Enter monsieur sensuality, and breaks off their dialogue-discourse.

sp.speaker: Sensuality.
sp.p: Jove bless us! what designs have you ladies and gentlemen that you sit so gravely together in council.

sp.speaker: Portrait.
sp.p: Our chief design is wit.

sp.speaker: Sensuality.
sp.p: A witty design: but really, what are you doing?

sp.speaker: Temperance.
sp.p: They are idly rhyming.

sp.speaker: Sensuality.
sp.p: Hang idle rhyming, give me reason.

sp.speaker: Ambition.
sp.p: Although our rhymes are not good, yet they are not foul, by reason they are made on fair and pure subjects.

sp.speaker: Sensuality.
sp.p: Why, what are the subjects they are made on?

sp.speaker: Portrait.
sp.p: They are made of the several seasons and months of the year.

sp.speaker: Sensuality.
sp.p: By your favour, lady, there be some of the seasons and months very foul.

sp.speaker: Pleasure.
sp.p: But we have rhymed of none but the fair months as yet.

sp.speaker: Sensuality.
sp.p: Then let me advise you to stop your poetical vein: for if you go farther, you will meet with foul weather and rain.

sp.speaker: They all speak.
sp.p: Out, out of our company.

sp.speaker: Faction.
sp.p: Do you come here to rail at our rhymes, and yet rhyme yourself, and worse than any of the company?

sp.speaker: Sensuality.
sp.p: I only rhyme to make myself free of the company, though not of the wits.

sp.speaker: Inquisitive.
sp.p: So you will call us fools by and by.

sp.speaker: Sensuality.
sp.p: No faith, your rhymes have named you already, and so prevented me.

sp.speaker: Portrait.
sp.p: Why this is worse and worse.

sp.speaker: Faction.
sp.p: Let us seek a revenge.

sp.speaker: Ambition.
sp.p: What revenge shall we take?

sp.speaker: Pleasure.
sp.p: We will tie him to an ass's head.

sp.speaker: Superbe.
sp.p: No, we will tie him to a fox's tail.

sp.speaker: Sensuality.
sp.p: Ladies tie me to what you please, so you do not tie me to a horn.

sp.speaker: Faction.
sp.p: Yes, to Althaea's horn, the horn of plenty.

sp.speaker: Sensuality.
sp.p: 'Tis a sign Althaea is a woman, that she gives her gifts in a horn; but I had rather starve, than receive plenty in such a thing.

sp.speaker: Portrait.
sp.p: Let us transform him as Actaeon did.

sp.speaker: Faction.
sp.p: And follow him as his hounds did.

sp.speaker: Temperance.
sp.p: Young ladies, be not so wild and fierce, to be the hounds yourselves to follow in pursuit.

sp.speaker: Portrait.
sp.p: No, no, we will be as Diana, that transformed him.

sp.speaker: Temperance.
sp.p: Then you must be liable to the same censure, which is, to be thought cruel.

sp.speaker: Superbe.
sp.p: The more cruel our sex is, the more chaste we are thought to be.

div.head: Epilogue
div.l: Our authoress bids me tell you she thought fit
For to divide this fair cabal of wit.
For one play 'twas too long, which was her sorrow,
The other half, if come, you'll see tomorrow.
You'll thank her then, dividing it to make
You rise with appetites, no surfeits take.
Wit's surfeit's dangerous: take the fruition
But hold your hands, as you are men today,
And as our friends tomorrow clap our play.
div.byline: the marquess of Newcastle writ this epilogue.

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-dit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a kewyord in context.
